Description: Memphis, Tennessee, is the closest city to Yoknapatawpha, and a place where locals frequently go for a variety of reasons (149). In this text, Max Harriss uses it as an alibi when he checks into the city's Greenbury Hotel. According to Gavin Stevens, "there was a saying in North Mississippi that the state begins in the lobby of the Greenbury hotel" (202). "The Greenbury" is Faulkner's imaginative reference to the famed Peabody Hotel in Memphis, the original source of Gavin's saying.

OtherTexts: "A Rose for Emily", "Dry September", "Elly", "Fool About a Horse", "Go Down, Moses", "Hair", "Smoke", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Reivers , The Sound and the Fury, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: Jefferson was built at the center of Yoknapatawpha, and at the center of Jefferson is Courthouse Square - or "square," as the the narrator alternately does and doesn't capitalize this site (see 199 vs 210, etc.). Around it are located the town's main businesses and offices, for example the movie house and Gavin Stevens' office. In particular, it is where the townspeople see Mrs. Harriss and her children when they drive through it in their automobiles.

OtherTexts: "By the People", "Go Down, Moses", "Hair", "Tomorrow", Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, The Mansion, The Reivers , The Town
Description: The office where Gavin Stevens practices as a lawyer and serves Yoknapatawpha as the County Attorney is located on the Square. Like other professional offices around the courthouse, it is one flight up from the street. A set of outside stairs leads to a gallery that overlooks the street, and the office is off of that (237).

OtherTexts: "Elly", Sanctuary, The Town
Description: The Sartoris twins enroll at the University of Virginia, in Charlottesville, but when the family decides to "separate 'em," as Jenny puts it, Bayard remains here while his brother Johnny is sent to Princeton (380).

Johnny Sartoris is sent to Princeton University in New Jersey after the family decides the twins have to be separated; according to Jenny, "they shot dice or something," and "Johnny lost," so he had to leave the University of Virginia (380-81).

OtherTexts: The Mansion, The Town
Description: The "old plantation" on the "good land" north of Jefferson where the Harrisses live was probably built before the Civil War as a slave plantation.  Its more recent history is a major focus of the story, as it evolves (or, the narrative suggests, devolves) from a cotton farm worked by sharecroppers to one worked by wage laborers under the control of a non-local manager to a thoroughbred stable and show place owned by Mr. Harriss, who lives there only for a fraction of the year. The narrative describes in detail how Harriss "transmogrifies" a "once-simple country house" into a "county (or for that matter, a north Mississippi) landmark: a mile square of white panel and rail paddock- and pasture-fences and electric-lit stables" (141). The story gives a lot of historical background, referred to as "legend," about the plantation. For example, Charles remembers it this way: "the old plantation six miles from town which had been an old place even in his grandmother's time, not so big in acreage but of good land properly cared for and worked, with the house on it which was not large either but was just a house, a domicile, more spartan even than comfortable" (150). Interestingly, the plantation is described as a gentleman-scholar-farmer's residence: "and the widower-owner who stayed at home and farmed his heritage and, with a constant tumbler of thin whiskey-and-water at his elbow and the aged setter bitch dozing at his feet, sat through the long summer afternoons in a home-made chair on the front gallery, reading in Latin the Roman poets" (150). Beyond the gallery was a "garden which was just a garden, overgrown, shabby too, of old permanent perennial things: nameless roses and lilac bushes and daisies and phlox and the hard durable dusty bloom of fall" (242). Gavin Stevens remembers the garden in detail: "It was a good deal bigger than even five or six rugs, spread side by side, with old bushes of roses and callicanthus and paintless collapsing arbors and trellises and beds of perennials re-seeding themselves without outside meddling help" (246). All this is before it becomes the property of a rich bootlegger from New Orleans: "Harriss took command of the plantation," dramatically modernizing it, with "electric lights and running water in the house, and the day-long, night-long thump and hum of the pump and dynamo were the mechanical sounds where there used to be the creak of the hand-turned well-pulley and of the ice-cream freezer on Sunday mornings" (159). Eventually Harriss rents the farmland out to a man who commutes to it from Memphis to work the land with heavy machinery, and people from the country drive to watch as it is surrounded by white-painted fences, long stables built with better material than most of their homes, "with electric lights and illuminated clocks and running water and screened windows" (161). Harriss also rebuilds the house into a "monstrosity" (170) where he entertains his friends from New Orleans: "It had been just a house, of one storey [sic], with the gallery across the front where the old master would sit in his home-made chair with his toddy and his Catullus; when Harriss got through with it, it looked like the Southern mansion in the moving picture, only about five times as big and ten times as Southern" (162). Charles Mallison notes the opulence of the grounds when he walks them: "the house that was too big, across the lawn where the bushes and shrubs were too many, past the garages that would have held more cars than just four people could ever have used and the conservatoires and hothouses of too many flowers and grapes for just four people to ever have eaten or smelled" (226). The grounds include a polo field and steeplechase course (226), and a small stable built by Captain Gualdres away from the estate's main stables - these last two sites have their own entries in the database.
Other Structure: Plantation; Stable; Sports Facility; Entertainment Site; Garden|Arbor

OtherTexts: "An Error in Chemistry", "By the People", "Hand Upon the Waters", "Tomorrow", Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion, The Town
Description: Gavin Stevens and his married sister Maggie live in separate parts of the house has been in the Stevens family for at least two generations. Here is the way another occupant of the house - Gavin's nephew, Charles Mallison - explains the living arrangement in a later fiction, The Town (1957), about a slightly earlier time in the family's history: "We were all living with Grandfather then. . . . he and Uncle Gavin had one side of the house, Grandfather in his bedroom and what we called the office downstairs, and Uncle Gavin on the same side upstairs, where he had built an outside stairway so he could go and come from the side yard, and Mother and Father and Cousin Gowan on the other side." "Grandfather" does not appear in this story, and it's likely that his 'office' has become Gavin's "private sitting room," where the story begins (148). Charles has his own room "upstairs" (204).

OtherTexts: The Mansion
Description: The "country club" in Yoknapatawpha is mentioned when Temple sums up, with some bitterness, the life she and Gowan led after their marriage: one of the fashionable elements in it was "a country club with a country club younger set of rallying friends" with whom to drink on Saturday nights (124). She gives no indication of the club's location, so the place we have assigned it on the map is entirely speculative.

OtherTexts: "A Rose for Emily", "Beyond", "There Was a Queen", "Vendee", Absalom, Absalom!, As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, Light in August, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: The "graveyard" where Gowan and Temple's murdered child is buried is the Jefferson cemetery that appears often in Faulkner's fictions (154).

At least one of the Scenes in the three-act drama in Requiem for a Nun are set in the Jefferson apartment where Gowan and Temple Stevens live. Faulkner's stage direction describes the apartment building as "an old house, an ante-bellum house," that has been cut up into apartments and "modernized"; the living room where Act I, Scene II, occurs is "smart, modern, up-to-date," but also expressing "the air of another time" (41). There is some confusion, however, about this setting. Later Temple herself says that "the Gowan Stevenses" live in "a new bungalow on the right [i.e. fashionable] street" (124). Scene II in Act II is set in "Temple's private apartment," with "a private entrance . . . from outdoors" (136), which could be in either the apartment house or the bungalow.

OtherTexts: "By the People", The Mansion
Description: In his account of the changes that progress brings to Yoknapatawpha, the narrator mentions that most tenant farms have disappeared along with the mules as workers on tractors cultivate larger tracts of land. This icon represents the few "forty- and fifty- and sixty-acre hill farms inaccessible from unmarked dirt roads" that still exist in the poorest parts of the county (193).

This location represents Negro residences mentioned by the narrator in his account of how the town of Jefferson has progressed over the years: "there were electric lights and running water in almost every house in town except the cabins of Negroes" (189).

As part of the growth of the town of Jefferson, a number of "new subdivisions" with names like "Fairfield or Longwood or Halcyon Acres" are built on lots "which had once been the lawn or back yard or kitchen garden of the old residences" (196). The "new minute glass-walled houses set as neat and orderly and antiseptic as cribs in a nursery ward" are ranged around "the old obsolete columned houses" of an earlier day (196).

OtherTexts: "All the Dead Pilots", "Ambuscade", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Raid", "Retreat", "Shall Not Perish", "Skirmish at Sartoris", "The Unvanquished", "There Was a Queen", Flags in the Dust, Sanctuary, The Mansion, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: The Sartoris plantation "four miles to the north" of town is one of the most frequently visited locations in the Yoknapatawpha fictions, but in this novel Faulkner adds a new element to its history. As part of the battle of Jefferson during the Civil War, "a sudden battle centering around Colonel Sartoris's plantation house" erupts (182). There is an invented, comic "Battle of Harrykin Creek" near the plantation in one of Faulkner's short stories, but apparently the fighting along "the line of a creek" here is a real but minor skirmish at Sartoris that ends when the Confederates retreat southward through the town and the Union forces occupy it (182). We are also using this plantation to represent the collected "plantation houses" with their "columned porticoes" that the narrator mentions elsewhere to indicate the way the county grows (179).

The coal house behind the county jail becomes a makeshift jail itself when Temple and Gavin visit Nancy. In a disconcerting reminder of the etiquette of Jim Crow segregation, the jailer shows deference to the couple's white race by moving the five "other nigger prisoners" to "the coal house" behind the jail (208). Ordinarily this shed is where the coal used for heating and cooking is stored.

OtherTexts: "Mule in the Yard", Flags in the Dust, Light in August, The Mansion, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: In the decade after the Civil War, Redmond and Sartoris and Compson build "a railroad from Jefferson north into Tennessee" that connects with the track between Memphis and the Atlantic (187).

OtherTexts: "A Rose for Emily", "Dry September", "Elly", "Hair", "Shall Not Perish", "Smoke", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, Go Down, Moses, Sanctuary, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury, The Town

When Union forces attack Jefferson during the Civil War, the Confederates fall back "to a stronger line on the river heights south of the town" (182). There does not seem to be any fighting there, though the Yankees occupy and burn the town itself.

In the other Yoknapatawpha fictions in which it appears, this store is owned by Will Varner.

Description: In the early days of Yoknapatawpha, outsiders often reached the area by traveling by steamboat up the Tallahatchie River (also referred to in the novel as "Ikkemotubbe's old river," 176) to a "landing" that was originally "Ikkemotubbe's" too, but "which Sutpen now owned" by the time the marble columns for the courthouse arrived there on the last leg of their trip from Italy (36).

OtherTexts: "A Courtship", "A Justice", "Red Leaves", "The Old People", Go Down, Moses
Description: The Chickasaw tribe in Yoknapatawpha calls their village their "plantation," "patterning [i.e. imitating] the white people" who settle in the county (28). Only mentioned in the novel, this "plantation" is described in detail in stories like "Red Leaves" and "A Courtship."

OtherTexts: "A Justice", "Red Leaves", "Vendee", Absalom, Absalom!, Flags in the Dust, Go Down, Moses
Description: This is the "swamp" where the architect who tried to escape from Sutpen was caught (33).

OtherTexts: "Wash", Absalom, Absalom!
Description: The narrative mentions the "tract" of land acquired by "a man named Sutpen" and on which he is "bent on establishing a place on an ever more ambitious and grandiose scale than Grenier's" (30) - a story that Faulkner tells in Absalom, Absalom!. ("Ever" may be a typo for "even.")

Description: For much of Yoknapatawpha's history, the railroad station in Jefferson is the portal through which people came from or departed to the larger world. In this novel it is only mentioned, when the narrator notes how in the "new century" the "entire street between the depot and the hotel" has been paved (189).

OtherTexts: Intruder in the Dust, The Town
Description: "The blacksmith's" shop was one of the settlement's earliest buildings; "a century and a quarter later," it has been replace by or transformed into "a garage" (167).

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", The Mansion, The Town
Description: The "Female Academy" in Jefferson was built a "half-century" after the first courthouse (36), but the same "molds and kilns" for the bricks were used in its construction (177). According to the narrator, "to a young woman of North Mississippi or West Tennessee" a graduation "certificate" from this finishing school would be as valuable as an "invitation . . . signed by Queen Victoria" would be to "a young female from Long Island or Philadelphia" (177).

OtherTexts: "Hair", "Uncle Willy", Absalom, Absalom!, The Town
Description: The "two churches" in Jefferson that were built about the same time as the antebellum courthouse were built out of bricks from the same "molds and kilns" as the courthouse (177). The novel does not specify their denomination, but all the churches in Yoknapatawpha are Protestant. When Temple refers later to the fact that she and Gowan belonged to "the right church" in 20th century Jefferson (124), she is probably referring to the Episcopal church, where upper class characters worship in other Yoknapatawpha fictions. One of these first two churches may have been Episcopal - but they could also have been Methodist, Baptist or Methodist.

OtherTexts: "A Rose for Emily", "Gold Is Not Always", "Miss Zilphia Gant", Flags in the Dust, The Town
Description: Like the courthouse at the center of Jefferson's Square, the offices and stores at its circumference were burned by the Union Army during the Civil War, but even before the South's surrender "the gutted walls . . . of the Square had been temporarily roofed and were stores and shops and offices again" (186). The growth of Yoknapatawpha results in new commercial buildings in the town, summed up by the narrative as "the counting-rooms of merchants and bankers and the sanctums of lawyers" (179). In the 20th century the stores are transformed by "sheets of [plate] glass" and the "corpse-glare of fluorescent light" (192). The description of "the stores" and "the offices of the lawyers and doctors and dentists" notes the distinctive "two storey" design of these buildings (31).

OtherTexts: Light in August
Description: The growth of Yoknapatawpha leads to the need for "the county offices . . . of sheriff and tax-collector and bailiff and turnkey and clerk" (179).

OtherTexts: The Sound and the Fury
Description: During the building of the original courthouse, Grenier and Sutpen "set up camps beside the creek in Compson's pasture" for their slaves (33). At some point a bridge is built over the creek - now referred to as "Compson's creek" - and at this spot the Chickasaws who are coming to the store stop to "bathe their legs and feet" before putting on their "pants and shoes" (173).

Description: The first Compson in Yoknapatawpha swaps a "race-horse" to the chief of the Chickasaw for "a square mile of what was to be the most valuable land in the future town of Jefferson" (11).

"The courthouse: the center, the focus, the hub" (32). The county courthouse and the Square around it are at the center of Jefferson, and together this site appears more frequently in the fictions than any other location. In Requiem it is a significant location in both the prose and the dramatic sequences. The brief first scene of the play is set in the "Courtroom" (38), represented in stylized fashion as an "intermediate . . . stage" in society's system of "justice" (39). The prose sections that introduce Act I and Act III trace the history of the structure that contains the courtroom from its origins in "a grove of oaks" opposite "the tavern and the store" that formed the nucleus of the original settlement (31) to the building of the "by-neo-Greek-out-of-Georgian-England edifice" (167), through the burning of the courthouse and the buildings on the Square by the Union Army during the Civil War, to the rebuilding that followed. In 1900, the local "U.D.C. ladies" (members of the United Daughters of the Confederacy) erect a memorial to the Confederacy on the south side of the courthouse. And "now," the narrator notes, in the middle of the 20th century, all the roads around the courthouse are "paved" (191) and the "courthouse yard" is "dotted" with benches and "potted conifers" (199).Our project also uses the "Courthouse and Square" as the default setting for events that take place at otherwise unspecified places in Jefferson.

LocationTitle: European Theater in World War II
Description: "Warsaw" (along with Dunkirk) appears in the narrative in its account of how black farmers and field hands in Yoknapatawpha left the region or became otherwise unavailable for working on the big plantations (193). The pairing with "Dunquerque" (as Faulkner spells it) makes it clear that the reference is to the beginning of World War II in Europe: Poland was invaded by the German army on 1 September 1939; the U.S. government began drafting young men, including young Negroes, in 1940.

OtherTexts: "Two Soldiers", Flags in the Dust, Go Down, Moses, Light in August, The Mansion, The Reivers , The Unvanquished
Description: The narrator measures the way that 20th century America is becoming "one nation" (rather than a North and a South) by noting the "Brooklyn exchange students" who attend college on the G.I. bill "at Mississippi or Arkansas or Texas universities" and sell "tiny confederate battle flags" at football games (194).

OtherTexts: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury, The Town
Description: Measuring the distance between 20th century Jefferson and its southern past, the narrator notes that the sons of the remaining Confederate veterans of the Civil War - "those tottering old men in gray" - had fought and died "in blue coats in Cuba," a reference to the Spanish-American War of 1898 (189).

OtherTexts: Sanctuary
Description: The narrator speculates about what kinds of local stories the people who lived in Yoknapatawpha could tell their friends or relatives from elsewhere who "passed through Jefferson on the way to New Orleans or Florida" (196).

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", "Shall Not Perish", "Uncle Willy", Sanctuary, The Town
Description: Stanford, the prestigious university in Palo Alto, California, is mentioned as one of the places at which the novel's hypothetical non-Southern reader may have been educated: "yourself the stranger, the outlander from B.A. (or perhaps even M.A.) at Harvard or Northwestern or Stanford" (205).

OtherTexts: "Appendix: Compson", "Uncle Willy", Absalom, Absalom!, Light in August, The Mansion, The Town
Description: Temple and her family take refuge from the events in Yoknapatawpha by going to a beach in California. As Temple tells her son, the beach is "far from Jefferson" (61), but the text gives no additional details about it. We are assuming the beach is in Southern California, perhaps as far south as San Diego.

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", "Shall Not Perish", "Uncle Willy", Sanctuary, The Town
Description: At the start of World War II the U.S. government created internment camps to which the Japanese-Americans living on the west coast were removed as a possible threat to the war effort against Japan. The novel refers to "a California detention camp for enemy aliens" (194), though almost two-thirds of the 110,000-120,000 people interned were American citizens, and though it's not clear that any were "enemies." Two of the ten camps on the U.S. mainland were in California; Japanese-Americans from northern California and further north were interned at Tule Lake, but it's likely that Faulkner was thinking of the camp at Manzanar, opened in March, 1942, as the first camp, and where Japanese-Americans from the Los Angeles area were taken. About a quarter of the people who were interned were in these two California camps.

OtherTexts: "Skirmish at Sartoris", "The Unvanquished", Absalom, Absalom!, Flags in the Dust, The Hamlet, The Unvanquished
Description: Charleston, South Carolina, a major port on the Atlantic, is mentioned in the novel as one end of the "constricting loop" that Union forces are drawing around the remaining Confederates during the last months of the Civil War (184).

OtherTexts: "Centaur in Brass", "Knight's Gambit", "Spotted Horses", "Two Soldiers", "Uncle Willy", "Vendee", Absalom, Absalom!, Light in August, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: Texas is mentioned three times in the novel. It is one of the places in "the West" to which the Confederate soldiers who are not willing to surrender at the end of the Civil War decide to go (204); this is a role "Texas" plays in a number of the fictions - a generic place to escape to and start over. "Texas" is also vaguely defined as the location of some of the "universities" that veterans of World War II choose to attend on the G.I. Bill (194). But one specific Texas location is identified: Gowan is absent from Jefferson fishing in "Aransas Pass" - a town on the Gulf of Mexico north of Corpus Christi - when the murder at the center of the novel's drama occurs (136).

OtherTexts: "Hand Upon the Waters"
Description: "The West" is mentioned by the narrative as one of the places to which the Confederate soldiers who are unwilling to surrender at Appomattox depart; it is ambiguously mentioned in the middle of two more specific western locations - "Texas, the West, New Mexico" - so it is uncertain what specific part of that "new land" the narrator is referring (204).

OtherTexts: "Delta Autumn", Go Down, Moses, Light in August, The Hamlet
Description: New Mexico is one of the places to which the Confederate soldiers who refuse to surrender at Appomattox depart.

OtherTexts: "A Rose for Emily", "Elly", "Hair", "Race at Morning", "Raid", "The Unvanquished", "Vendee", Sanctuary, The Mansion, The Reivers , The Unvanquished
Description: Alabama appears peripherally in the novel as the place where [Nathan Bedford] Forrest is fighting as the Civil War draws to a close (184) and the place where Popeye is "hanged for a murder he did not commit" (114). It figures more directly as the site of "the small hill farm" (185) about "a hundred miles" from Jefferson (203) that is owned by the family of the Confederate lieutenant with whom Cecilia Farmer falls in love. The narrative never takes us there, but does evoke the "churns and stoves and brooms and stacks of wood" of life on such a farm (203).

OtherTexts: "Ambuscade", "Appendix: Compson", "Raid", Absalom, Absalom!, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: In his reference to the final months of the Civil War, the narrator refers to "[General] Johnston in Georgia" and to "Atlanta" (184).

OtherTexts: "Appendix: Compson", "Knight's Gambit", "Lion", Light in August, The Mansion, The Town
Description: Mexico appears obliquely in the novel in the phrase "Maximilian of Mexico," whom the narrator uses as a point of reference to make exceptional the "dream" that a Missourian like Mark Twain or a man from Yoknapatawpha acquires from his culture, the idea of the frontier and freedom (205).

OtherTexts: "Skirmish at Sartoris", "Two Soldiers", Absalom, Absalom!, The Unvanquished
Description: Missouri is mentioned in the novel in the context of Mark Twain, whose "Missouri dream" is comparable to "the Yoknapatawpha dream too" (205): both privilege the idea of freedom and the frontier (205).
Lake Louise is a resort area in the Canadian Rockies; Temple mentions it as one of the places where her family might go after their stay in California (44).

OtherTexts: "Ad Astra", "Appendix: Compson", "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", Flags in the Dust, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury, The Town
Description: New York is mentioned four times in the novel: as a reference point for measuring how much more of the world the soldiers who went from Yoknapatawpha to serve overseas during World War II have seen (193); as the hometown of "young men from Brooklyn" who attend southern colleges on the G.I. Bill and sell "tiny confederate battle flags" at Saturday football games (194); as the location of the "East Side sweat-shops" where the clothes that the Yoknapatawpha children of Negro and poor whites are made (192); and as one of the northern and western cities to which the Negroes who formerly farmed the land have moved in the 20th century (193).

OtherTexts: "Shall Not Perish", "Two Soldiers", Flags in the Dust
Description: "Hawaii" figures in two different ways in the stories Faulkner is telling in the novel: in Act I of the drama, Temple tells Gavin that her family "may go on to Hawaii in the spring" (44); they don't, but by 1929 an average of about 22,000 tourists visited the islands annually. In the prose introduction to Act III, as part of the account of how the racial demographics of Yoknapatawpha change during the 20th century the narrator mentions "Pearl Harbor," by which he means the surprise Japanese attack on the U.S. naval base in Hawaii on 7 December 1941 that plunged the nation into World War II (193).

In his account of the role the nation's "mid-continent fluvial" rivers played in its historical development, Faulkner's narrator claims that Pittsburgh (on the Ohio River) and "Fort Bridger, Wyoming, were suburbs one to the other" (83) - connected by the various waterways that drained into the Mississippi River. In fact, however, Fort Bridger - a stopping point on the Oregon Trail - was on the far side of the Continental Divide; its water flowed to the Pacific, not the Gulf of Mexico.

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", Intruder in the Dust, Light in August
Description: The city of Detroit was a major manufacturing center during most of the 20th century, making it a magnet for many of the African-Americans who moved from the South to northern cities. The narrator refers to the "ghettoes" of Detroit as one of the places (along with those of "New York and Chicago and Los Angeles") to which the Negro tenant farmers and "furnish-hands" who worked in Yoknapatawpha's fields have moved by the 1930s (193).

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", "Shall Not Perish", "Uncle Willy", Sanctuary, The Town
Description: The "ghettoes" of Los Angeles are one of the places (along with those of "New York and Detroit and Chicago") to which the Negro tenant farmers and "furnish-hands" who worked in Yoknapatawpha's fields have moved by the 1930s (193). Nearby "Hollywood," where Faulkner often worked as a screenwriter during the 1930s and 40s but where he never felt at home, appears in the novel as an adjective in the unseemly phrase "trick Hollywood bathroom" (123).

OtherTexts: The Town
Description: Kansas City (along with "Chicago and Boston and Philadelphia") is cited as an epitome of municipal political corruption (192).
Philadelphia (along with "Chicago and Kansas City and Boston") is cited as an epitome of municipal political corruption (192).

Description: Boston (along with "Chicago and Kansas City and Philadelphia") is cited as an epitome of municipal political corruption (192). Harvard, the prestigious university in Cambridge, Massachusetts, just next to Boston, is mentioned as one of the places at which the novel's hypothetical non-Southern reader may have been educated: "yourself the stranger, the outlander from B.A. (or perhaps even M.A.) at Harvard or Northwestern or Stanford" (205).

OtherTexts: "Ad Astra", "Appendix: Compson", "Go Down, Moses", Go Down, Moses, Light in August, The Town
Description: Chicago (along with "Kansas City and Boston and Philadelphia") is cited as an epitome of municipal political corruption (192). The "ghettoes" of Chicago are one of the places (along with those of "New York and Detroit and Los Angeles") to which the Negro tenant farmers and "furnish-hands" who worked in Yoknapatawpha's fields have moved by the 1930s (193). "Northwestern," the private university located in Evanston, Illinois, about a dozen miles north of Chicago, is mentioned as one of the places at which the novel's hypothetical non-Southern reader may have been educated: "yourself the stranger, the outlander from B.A. (or perhaps even M.A.) at Harvard or Northwestern or Stanford" (205).

OtherTexts: The Sound and the Fury
Description: Pittsburgh is first mentioned (along with Fort Bridger, Wyoming) as proof of how connected the interior of the nation is by its waterways during the 19th century (83), and again as the site of the "factories" that make the sheets of plate glass for the windows of 20th century Jefferson's stores (192).

OtherTexts: "Red Leaves", Absalom, Absalom!, The Hamlet, The Reivers
Description: During the Western Desert Campaign in World War II (1940-1943), Tobruk was held for 241 days by Allied forces - mostly Australian; there were no American troops engaged. There was fighting in many parts of "the African desert" during the War, and Japanese-American troops fighting in Europe accumulated an impressive combat record, but no Japanese-American troops were involved in fighting in Africa (194).

Description: Founded in 1819 on the banks of the Mississippi River, Memphis, Tennessee, is the closest big city to Jefferson and it appears in almost half the 69 Yoknapatawpha fictions. In Requiem it is from "the Memphis airport" that Temple and her family fly to California (44). Much more importantly, the story that Temple is so reluctant to tell mostly takes place in seamier parts of Memphis, in the "Manuel Street sporting house" (i.e. house of prostitution, 111), "the back alleys of the redlight district" (113), and Popeye's "nightclub, joint, on the outskirts of town" (114). Later the novel links Memphis with New Orleans as places where people from Yoknapatawpha are likely to go to misbehave during "a few prolonged Saturday nights" (205).

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", Absalom, Absalom!, The Town
Description: The "eight disjointed marble columns" that are assembled in Jefferson for the courthouse are imported from Italy (36).
Cap Ferrat (Cape Ferrat) - where Temple and Gowan spend their honeymoon in a villa built by a prince for his mistress - is a very exclusive community on the Mediterranean in the south of France.

Two French locations that were prominent parts of the history of the Second World War are referred to in the novel. "Dunquerque" (more commonly anglicized as Dunkirk) was the coastal city in northern France from which England had to evacuate its army after German forces overran the country in May 1940, near the start of the War (193). "Utah Beach" was the code name that the Allies gave to the westernmost of the five Normandy beaches where the D-Day invasion of occupied France began on 6 June 1944 (193).

OtherTexts: "Ad Astra", "All the Dead Pilots", "Death Drag", "The Tall Men", "There Was a Queen", "Two Soldiers", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, The Mansion, The Town
Description: "The Western Front" refers to the battle line across which the German and the allied armies faced each other for most of World War I; the experiences of a "combat airman" like young Bayard Sartoris in the War are described in detail in several other Yoknapatawpha fictions (190).

OtherTexts: "Appendix: Compson", "Knight's Gambit", "Red Leaves", Sanctuary
Description: Temple spends a "year in Europe, Paris," and she and Gowan are married at the American Embassy there (121). The Crillon, where their reception is held, a luxury hotel which opened in Paris in 1909. The palace at Versailles, near Paris, is also mentioned in the novel as a facetious standard of comparison for the massive house that the "Paris architect" builds for Sutpen (32).

OtherTexts: "Red Leaves", Absalom, Absalom!
Description: The language spoken by the slaves that Sutpen brings to Yoknapatawpha is identified by Compson as "the Caribbean-Spanish-French of the Sugar Islands" (30). Better known as the West Indies, the islands of the Caribbean used slave labor to produce most the world's sugar at the time Yoknapatawpha was settled.

OtherTexts: "Appendix: Compson", Absalom, Absalom!
Description: The Mississippi River and the towns that grew up along its banks - "St Louis, Paducah, Memphis, Helena, Vicksburg, Natchez, Baton Rouge" (82) - appears in the novel as a major element in the historical story that Yoknapatawpha is part of. The antebellum era as a "new age" for the nation flows through the "vast single net of commerce webbed and veined [by the waters of] the mid-continent's fluvial embracement" (83). Jefferson lies "about midway between" the River and the Natchez Trace (6).

LocationTitle: Filling Station on Road to Jackson
Description: On their trip from Jefferson to Jackson, Gavin and Temple stop at a "filling station" (162), which we would call a gas station. Gavin tells her they need to "change the wheel," but the real purpose of the stop is to give Gowan time to get to Jackson ahead of them (163).

OtherTexts: "The Tall Men", Sanctuary, The Hamlet
Description: Temple is supposed to be traveling by "special train" from the University of Mississippi to "a baseball game at another college" when she goes off instead with Gowan Stevens (100). The other college is almost certainly Mississippi State, which is in Starkville, about 90 miles away.

OtherTexts: "The Unvanquished", Absalom, Absalom!, Flags in the Dust, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury, The Town
Description: Oxford, Mississippi - where Faulkner himself lived most of his life - is the home of the University of Mississippi, which is "the University" that Temple was attending "eight years ago" (100). Temple herself refers to the railroad station "at the University" as the place where Nancy's "journey" began "that morning eight years ago" (164). Faulkner's Jefferson is largely derived from Oxford, but there is no college in his fictional town.

OtherTexts: Sanctuary
Description: Temple's dark misadventure begins when she gets off the train "at an intermediate stop," where she is met by Gavin Stevens (100). In Sanctuary (1931), where Temple's story is first told, the stop is identified as Taylor, Mississippi, a real town not far from Oxford.

According to the novel, in 1820 Columbia was the temporary location of the Mississippi legislature when the Commission to choose the site of a capital for the new State was authorized (84). Although the novel does not say so, Columbia was named for Columbia, South Carolina, from which many of its early settlers, like many of the inhabitants of Yoknapatawpha, had migrated.
Port Gibson began in the 18th century as part of the French territory "La Louisiane." According to the novel, in 1830 it was considered as a new location for the state capital (86).

OtherTexts: "Ambuscade", "Delta Autumn", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Race at Morning", Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, The Unvanquished
Description: Vicksburg, a city on steep bluffs overlooking the Mississippi River, is mentioned in the novel as the port where the marble for the courthouse columns were transferred from a New Orleans steamboat to "a smaller steamboat" that could travel up the "Yazoo and Sunflower and Tallahatchie" rivers (36).

Yalo Busha (as Faulkner's narrator spells Yalobusha, an Indian word meaning "tadpole place") is a real county southwest of Lafayette, the real county on which his Yoknapatawpha is largely based. The Yalobusha River was part of the boundary between Choctaw and Chickasaw nations. In the novel Yalo Busha is mentioned as the site of an Indian agency.

OtherTexts: "A Point of Law", "By the People", "Knight's Gambit", "Monk", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", Sanctuary, The Mansion
Description: The city of Jackson was founded in 1821 to be the capital of Mississippi, which had achieved statehood in 1817. Its history from aboriginal times to the present is the subject of the prose narrative that begins "Act II" of Requiem. Locations within the area of the city that are mentioned in that section include Le Fleur's Bluff, the site of the trading post on the Natchez Trace that was there when the "three Commissioners" arrived to establish the capital's location (84), and the airport and radio stations of 1950 (88). Other locations that figure in the account are three Negro colleges (87), the Governor's mansion (87), Millsaps College (88), the Governor's office (89) - and dominating the section and the skyline, the capital building with "The Golden Dome" that gives Act II its title (79). Jackson is also the family home of Temple Drake. This location also includes Clinton, Mississippi, 10 miles from downtown Jackson and one of the places to which, in the state's early years, the legislators thought about moving the capital.

Doak's Stand was the site of a tavern established on the Natchez Trace by William Doak in about 1812. The novel's reference to how the "wilderness's dark denizens" were already "dispossessed at Doak's Stand" (84) refers to the treaty that the Choctaw Indians signed on 18 October 1820 with the United States, ceding about half of their homeland in Mississippi in return for land west of the Mississippi River.

Description: During the Civil War, "John Sartoris himself" led a "small gang of irregular cavalry" to Tennessee, where they fought with Nathan Bedford Forrest's troops (181). Chattanooga, Tennessee, where several battles took place in 1862 and 1863, is mentioned in the context of the "constricting loop" which the Union forces are drawing around the remaining Confederates during the last months of the war (184). The Battle of Shiloh, mentioned briefly in the narrative in the context of World War II, was fought in April, 1862 (194).

Description: Named for the Indian tribe who occupied much of southern Mississippi before they were "removed" in the 1830s, Natchez was founded by the French at the western end of the Natchez Trace from Nashville. During the antebellum period Natchez became an important river port, but the reason the courier heads there instead of to Nashville to inquire about the reward is probably Natchez's status as the original capital of the Mississippi Territory.

Description: Virginia appears in the novel in several different ways. Pettigrew is from Virginia - or as he puts it, "old Ferginny" (23) - which explains (in a very involved, some might say typically Faulknerian way) how Jefferson got its name. Because Richmond was the capitol of the Confederacy, the regiment formed in Jefferson was sworn in by a "Richmond mustering officer" (181). A number of major Civil War battles were fought in the state: First Manassas (36), Second Manassas (181), The Wilderness (194). The novel mentions Old Point Comfort, a fort on "the Atlantic Ocean," in connection with the last days of the War (184), as well as Appomattox, where Lee's surrender of his army brought the fighting to an end (184). And in the 20th century Gowan Stevens "went to the University of Virginia," where he "trained . . . not only in drinking but in gentility too" (103).

Description: Doctor Peabody says, just before they give the settlement a name, that "We already got a church"; according to him, "that's Whitfield's cabin" (213-14). The basis for his claim is probably that Whitfield (who does not otherwise appear in the story) holds some kind of regular religious service inside his cabin. In later Yoknapatawpha fictions, "Whitfield" is the name of a Protestant minister who preaches in Frenchman's Bend, but although this Whitfield is presumably an ancestor, his cabin must be in the immediate area that, a few sentences after Peabody's claim, acquires the name of Jefferson.

Description: The cotton plantation created in the southeastern part of the county by Louis Grenier (better known in Yoknapatawpha lore as 'the Old Frenchman') is the county's "first big land patent" (6). It is described as so "vast" that half of it is "not even in Yoknapatawpha County" (8), and "Frenchman's Bend" is its name: "Frenchman's Bend (his plantation: his manor, his kitchens and stables and kennels and slave quarters and gardens and promenades and fields" - though as the narrator goes on to say, "a hundred years later [it] will have vanished" (27). This isn't quite true, however. It is just about exactly one hundred years later that Grenier's decaying manor house is the "old moonshiner's house" where "the murder happened" and where Temple is "kidnapped and carried to Memphis" (101). ('Frenchman's Bend,' of course, will remain - as the name of the whole region.)

Description: The city of Nashville was originally founded in 1779. It is three hundred miles away from the settlement that becomes Jefferson, and reached by traveling the Natchez Trace. In this story, set in the early 19th century, it seems that Nashville was the point of contact between the settlers and the larger world, including the federal government which pays "a special horseman" to carry the mail "every two weeks" from "the post office in Nashville" and which might have frowned on the loss of the lock of the "Nashville mail-pouch" (202, 204).

Description: In Faulkner's landscapes a "bottom" is the low land that lies along a stream or river. The "swamp four miles away [from the settlement] known as Hurricane Bottoms" - the spot where the militia men capture the gang of outlaws - does not appear by that name elsewhere in Faulkner's Yoknapatawpha fictions (201). However, Hurricane Creek, occasionally called Harrykin Creek, flows through a number of those texts, where like the real Hurricane Creek in Lafayette County, it flows northward into the Tallahatchie River.

Description: The "Natchez Trace" (201) was a 440-mile trail through the wilderness originally created by Indians between Nashville, Tennessee, and Natchez, Mississippi. It linked three rivers - the Cumberland, the Tennessee and the Mississippi. In the 18th and early 19th centuries, it served as a major overland route for traders and settlers. Historically, it passed through northeast Mississippi to the east of Oxford; in the story the settlement is located "about midway between" the Mississippi River to the west and "the Trace" to the east (201). Although in the story the "special horseman" who carries the mail between the settlement and Nashville rides up and down it "every two weeks" with a kind of impunity (202), it is described as a lawless "region where for no more than the boots on his feet, men would murder a traveler" (204). The story's outlaw gang is identified as "Natchez Trace bandits" (201).

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "Appendix: Compson"
Description: The "Natchez Trace" (4) was a 440-mile trail through the wilderness originally created by Indians between Nashville, Tennessee, and Natchez, Mississippi. It linked three rivers - the Cumberland, the Tennessee and the Mississippi. In the 18th and early 19th centuries, it served as a major overland route for traders and settlers. Historically, it passed through northeast Mississippi to the east of Oxford. In the early history of Jefferson the Trace links the settlement to civilization back east: although the "special horseman" who carries the mail between the settlement and Nashville rides up and down it "every two weeks" with a kind of impunity (8), the "three hundred miles" he traverses is referred to as the "rapine-haunted Trace" (10), a lawless and violent "region where for no more than the boots on his feet, men would murder a traveler" (9). In time, however, the "trackless infested forest" through which the Trace passes becomes the route of "the pioneer" who "drags his gravid wife and most of the rest of his mother-in-law's family behind him" on the march of civilization westward (81).

One of the first three white settlers in Yoknapatawpha, the son of Doctor Habersham, marries a Chickasaw and "in the thirties [i.e. the 1830s] emigrates to Oklahoma with his wife's dispossessed people" (7).

This icon represents the residences of the earliest inhabitants of what will become (before the end of the story) the town of Jefferson. At the start of the story these residences are described as "a half-dozen log cabins set in a disorderly huddle in the middle of the wilderness" (200).

Description: The third act of the novel is titled "The Jail" (167), which gives this location an unusually large symbolic significance. Gavin Stevens himself "was wont to say" that the best way to learn "the history of a community" is to study the graffiti drawn by successive generations of prisoners on their cell walls (168). The novel does not include any examples of this record - though it gives a prominent thematic role to the name and date that the jailor's daughter left behind on a window pane in the jail, scratched there in 1861 by means of her diamond ring (180). Physically, the county jail begins as the "mortised-log, mud-chinked shake-down" building that is one of the first structures erected by the whites who settle Yoknapatawpha around the turn into the 19th century (4). When a gang of "Natchez trace bandits" (4) is locked up there, the jail also becomes the first Yoknapatawpha structure to be destroyed - or at least ruined: when the bandits break jail, they also break the jail, taking down one "entire wall," "the mud-chinked, axe-mortised logs unjointed neatly," removed, "and stacked as neatly to one side" (13). Repaired, the structure lasts until the mid-20th century, eventually being "translated into brick," although underneath this new facade the "old mud-chinked logs" remain as the ground floor of a two-story building (175). Prisoners are confined upstairs in the "bullpen and cell" (168); the downstairs has become "the living quarters for the turnkey's family" (179).

Description: The "mortised-log, mud-chinked shakedown jail" was one of the first structures built by the whites who settle Yoknapatawpha (201). It usually confines "local brawlers and drunkards and runaway slaves" (202). But when the gang of bandits is locked up there, the jail also becomes the first Yoknapatawpha structure to be destroyed - or at least ruined: when the bandits break jail, they also break the jail, taking down one "entire wall," "the mud-chinked, axe-mortised logs unjointed neatly," removed, "and stacked as neatly to one side" (208). It is rebuilt, however, and along with two other locations in this story of Yoknapatawpha's origins - the Holston House and the old Frenchman's place - it survives to the end of the stories; for that reason, we also use the jail as the Location for the narrator and Uncle Gavin in 1950.

Description: The Holston House was Jefferson's first tavern, founded by Alexander Holston, one of the town's original three white inhabitants. As the story notes, it "still" exists in Jefferson over a century later, with its "original log walls and puncheon floors and hand-mortised joints . . . still buried somewhere beneath the modern pressed glass and brick veneer and neon tubes" of the mid-20th century hotel (202). The kitchen of the Holston House is the site of "the settlement's first municipal meeting," as the settlers debate the right way to dispose of the settlement's first prisoners of note (206).

Description: The Holston House was Jefferson's first tavern, founded by Alexander Holston, one of the town's original three white inhabitants. As the narrative notes, is "still" exists in Jefferson over a century later, with its "original log walls and puncheon floors and hand-mortised joints . . . still buried somewhere beneath the modern pressed glass and brick veneer and neon tubes" of the mid-20th century "hotel" (7, 167). The kitchen of the Holston House is the site of "the settlement's first municipal meeting," as the settlers debate the right way to dispose of the settlement's first prisoners of note (12). It's likely that "the hotel" mentioned in Act III of the novel is also this one, although Jefferson hotels and boarding houses occur in a number of Faulkner's fictions under a variety of other names (e.g., Jefferson, Beard, Snopes, Commercial).

Description: Before Jefferson had a name, before it was even a village, it was a "Chickasaw agency trading post" - the place where the indigenous population of the region interacted with an agent appointed to represent the federal government in its dealings with them (3). It sells "calico and gunpowder, whiskey and salt and snuff and denim pants and osseous candy" to the Chickasaw Indians and their "Negro slaves," for which the U.S. government is billed (17). As the settlement grows, the agency becomes "Ratliffe's and Compson's general store," where the Indians buy "eastern factory-made jeans and shoes sold them on credit" (173). This "post-office-trading-post-store" contains at least two rooms, including the "back room" where the agency records were stored (3). It's likely that the agent also lived there.

In the story's introductory paragraph, Gavin Stevens imagines Homer, the classical Greek poet, sitting on a stone in Athens.

This is the place where, according to Charles' speculations, Gavin and Linda might find themselves "fumbling and panting in a parked automobile like they were seventeen years old" (236). It seems clear from the novel as a whole that nothing like this ever happens, so this 'location' exists mainly or entirely in Charles' mind, and the place we assign it on the map is more than usually tenuous.

The tavern on the route that Jim Gant takes from the Bend to Memphis is described as "a rambling log house with stout walls and broken roof"; the men who stay in it are "rough" and "unshaven," they drink "corn whiskey" and sleep in "their muddy clothes and boots," and "about the whole place lay an air of transient and sinister dilapidation" (368). The place is "conducted" by Mrs. Vinson, the woman whom Gant leaves his wife for (368).

When he marries again, the painter who married Zilphia is living "in a neighboring state" (379). Mississippi is bordered by Louisiana, Arkansas, Alabama and Tennessee. Tennessee is the most likely of these, in part because the newspaper where Zilphia learns of his new marriage is probably a Memphis paper, and also because the detective agency she hires to keep tabs on his new life is in Memphis. For these reasons we have put this location in Tennessee. It also contains "the hospital" where painter's new wife gives birth (380), and "the street" in front of the hospital where the painter himself is accidentally "killed by a motor car" (381).

Description: This is the "store" where Mrs. Gant buys the "miniature cook stove" for Zilphia (372). It's extremely unlikely that Faulkner's Jefferson ever included a toy store, so Faulkner might be thinking of the department store that appears in several other texts - but all this text says about the store is that, when Mrs. Gant returns the stove, "they" refund her money (373).

Of the houses "in three different parts of town" that are home to the three girls whom Zilphia tells her mother she would like to visit, this is the one that Mrs. Gant gives her "permission to visit" (373). On its property is also a "barn" where the two girls play in good weather, and "behind the barn" there is "a short pasture [that] slopes to a ditch where scrub cedars grew"; in this ditch Mrs. Gant sits to keep watch on her daughter until it is time for them to return home together (373).

Description: Zilphia attends school in Jefferson, though her mother takes her to and from school, and each day "at midmorning recess time" waits at "the corner of the playground" to make her daughter sit with her while the other children play (371).

The barred window in the room where the Gants live looks over "a vacant lot where farmers tethered their teams on market days" - which suggests proximity to the Square - "and where sparrows whirled in gusty clouds about the horse and mule droppings and the refuse from the grocery store" that occupies the building's ground floor (371). As they "hitch or unhitch" their teams, the farmers regularly see Zilphia's face in the window, "holding to the bars" (371).

The "dressmaking shop" that Mrs. Gant buys when she moves to Jefferson is also where she and Zilphia live for "twenty-three years" (371). It is one of the businesses and offices in Jefferson that are on the second story of the buildings around the Square, reached by an outside flight of "stairs to the street" (374); on its ground floor the building houses a grocery store (371). Mrs. Gant and Zilphia live in a "single room twelve feet square" in rear of shop, which "contained a bed, a table, two chairs and an oil stove" and a single "barred" window (371) - though later this back room is changed into a "fitting room" (375) and still later into "a day nursery" for the girl Zilphia herself is raising (381).
This is the "neighbor's house" where Mrs. Gant leaves Zilphia when she goes to Memphis (369).

LocationTitle: Neighbor's House where Mrs. Gant Borrows Pistol
Description: This is the house of the Mrs. Gant's other "neighbor," from whom she borrows the pistol that she takes with her on her trip to Memphis (369).
At the start of the story, Jim Gant lives with his wife and "two-year-old" daughter Zilphia in a "small house" somewhere in "the settlement" that the story refers to as "the Bend" (369, 371).

OtherTexts: "An Error in Chemistry", "By the People", "Centaur in Brass", "Fool About a Horse", "Hand Upon the Waters", "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", "Spotted Horses", "The Hound", "Tomorrow", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Town
Description: This country store is a gathering point for the inhabitants of "the Bend" (371), the "settlement" where Gants live at start of story (369). As "Varner's store" in "Frenchman's Bend," this location appears in 18 other Yoknapatawpha fictions. In "Miss Zilphia Gant," the unnamed store where Gant's "halfwitted" assistant tells and retells his grievance to the locals is not described (368), but the settlement is: "It was less than a village, twenty miles from the railroad in a remote section of a remote county" (369).

OtherTexts: As I Lay Dying, Intruder in the Dust, The Hamlet
Description: Whiteleaf is the small hamlet, probably smaller than Frenchman's Bend, where Grover Cleveland Winbush's mother lives. Our guess about its location is based both on the other texts in which "Whiteleaf" appears, and on the likelihood that Faulkner's imagination derived the place from the Yellow Leaf Creek that flows in Lafayette County.

Eula tells Gavin about the vacation Flem took her and Linda on in the summer after high school graduation, "to the coast" (339), "so she could swim in the ocean and meet people" (340). The Gulf of Mexico is not technically the "ocean," but it's likely that they went to one of the Mississippi resort towns on the Gulf, like Bay St. Louis, where the Priest family vacations in The Reivers.

OtherTexts: "Mule in the Yard"
Description: "The lot behind I.O. Snopes' mule barn" is where he pastures the mules he buys in Memphis (253). It is also where Buddy McCallum takes Matt Levitt and Anse McCallum to fight it out after he bails them out of jail.

OtherTexts: "A Point of Law", Go Down, Moses
Description: While the county courthouse at the center of Jefferson appears much more frequently in Faulkner's fictions, federal criminal cases - including the making and selling of alcohol or, in the case of Montgomery Ward Snopes, sending pornography through the mail - are tried in the town's federal courthouse.

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "Hand Upon the Waters", Requiem for a Nun, The Reivers
Description: The "Cumberland Gap" through which Sutpen brings the imported tombstones for his wife and himself is a narrow pass through the Cumberland Mountains near the intersection of the states of Kentucky, Virginia, and Tennessee. It was a major route over the Appalachians for the settlers who first inhabited the frontier southwest.

OtherTexts: "Skirmish at Sartoris", "The Unvanquished", Flags in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, The Hamlet, The Unvanquished
Description: "Sumter" is Fort Sumter, which guarded the harbor in Charleston, South Carolina. The first shots of the Civil War were fired when the fort was attacked by Confederates on 12 April 1861. The Union garrison there surrendered ("the fall of Sumter," 61) the next day.

The "French architect" who designs and helps construct the buildings and grounds at Sutpen's Hundred came to Yoknapatawpha "all the way from Martinique" (26). At that time Martinique was a French colony with an economy that depended on sugar and slaves.

OtherTexts: "Hair", "Miss Zilphia Gant", Intruder in the Dust, The Sound and the Fury, The Town
Description: The Jefferson school (or perhaps two schools, an elementary and a high school) is mentioned twice: resident Tug Nightingale drops out of school after getting "as far as the fourth grade" (202); on the other hand, Essie Meadowfill graduates from high school as the class valedictorian (361).

OtherTexts: "Smoke"
Description: Judge Dukinfield's office is a "little brick house back of the courthouse" (The Town 102). It is described in more detail in "Smoke," where it is a crime scene. There it is separated from the "courthouse proper" by a "flagged passage," though it can also be reached by "the narrow private stair which led down from the courtroom, used only by the presiding judge during court term" (14).

OtherTexts: "Death Drag", "That Will Be Fine", "The Unvanquished", Light in August, The Sound and the Fury, The Unvanquished
Description: This is the "straight stretch of road about two miles from town" where Manfred de Spain and Lucius Hogganbeck raced cars on Sunday afternoons (61).

OtherTexts: "A Bear Hunt", "Appendix: Compson", "Delta Autumn", "Dry September", "Lion", "The Bear", "The Old People", "Wash", Absalom, Absalom!, Go Down, Moses, The Reivers
Description: Major de Spain's "hunting camp" is located in "the Big Bottom," the wilderness area in the northwestern part of Yoknapatawpha (45). A major location in many of Faulkner's stories, the site is only mentioned briefly in The Town, which does not include the camp's history as having originally been built as a fishing camp by Thomas Sutpen.

OtherTexts: "Delta Autumn", Go Down, Moses, The Sound and the Fury
Description: Based on the fact that Caddy's first husband is "an extremely eligible young Indianian" (332), we assume that they were living in Indiana when he divorced her. (The Sound and the Fury identifies the city in Indiana as South Bend.)

The county courthouse and the Square around it that sit in the center of Jefferson is at the center of many of Faulkner's fictions. Its place in our representation of the "Appendix," however, is a function of the practice, throughout the Digital Yoknapatawpha data, to locate characters and events that cannot be associated with any specific location there, "in" the Square as an equivalent to "somewhere in Jefferson or Yoknapatawpha." Here, it is where the we locate these groups: "the whole town and county" (329) and Jason III's "living fellow townsmen" (330).

This icon represents the farms on which some of "Ikkemotubbe's descendants" remain after the tribe itself has been removed to Oklahoma - and also "what they too called plantations" (328), where some of these descendants owned slaves. The text gives no cues about where these places might have been, or how many of them there were, but does clearly suggest that the farms, the plantations and the Indians who owned them all disappeared "at last" - presumably some time after the Civil War (329).

OtherTexts: "By the People", "Centaur in Brass", "Fool About a Horse", "Shall Not Perish", "Shingles for the Lord", "Two Soldiers", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, Intruder in the Dust, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Town
Description: Frenchman's Bend is "the hamlet" (in the novel with that title and many other fictions) where the story of Flem Snopes begins. Its role in this last novel in the Snopes trilogy is much diminished, but the narrative does end there. As a place it is crisply brought into focus when, at the start of the final chapter, Stevens and Ratliff pass through it at night: "Varner's store and gin and blacksmith shop, and the church and the dozen or so dwellings and other edifices" (458). In this novel the land around the hamlet is described, perhaps surprisingly, as "flat rich valley land" (458). Yoknapatawpha, like real Mississippi counties, is divided into administrative districts called "beats." In all the rest of Faulkner's fictions, the highest number assigned any beat in Yoknapatawpha is five, but in The Mansion there are nine. Beat Two comprises the entirety of Frenchman's Bend, which Ratliff describes as Will "Varner's own private Beat" (326), since the landowner controls not only the finances of this area, but also all the officials who serve there.

This location represents the place where the German aviator who appears in "Ad Astra" as Monaghan's prisoner must have been stationed when, on the last day of World War I, he receives the news about his brother Franz's death. As he describes his subsequent actions, he says nothing about where he is at the time, but since he takes off in a plane, it must be an air base of some sort.

OtherTexts: "Ambuscade", "Hair", "Knight's Gambit", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Vendee", Absalom, Absalom!, Go Down, Moses, Requiem for a Nun, The Hamlet, The Unvanquished
Description: V.K. Ratcliffe - the son of the first Ratcliffe in the U.S. - migrates to Tennessee sometime during the antebellum era.

LocationTitle: Cotton House Where Wesley Snopes Is Caught
OtherTexts: The Town
Description: This is the "empty cotton house" where Wesley Snopes is "caught after church" with a 14-year-old girl (79).

OtherTexts: Requiem for a Nun
Description: As a young man Tyler Ballenbaugh "went out West," where he is rumored to have won a lot of money "gambling at cards" (75). This location represents that generic "West" - a familiar place in America's cultural mythology: a land of the particular kind of opportunity implied by "violence," "gambling," and vast "sums" (75).

LocationTitle: Road Between Jefferson and Frenchman's Bend
OtherTexts: "Fool About a Horse", "Shall Not Perish", "Spotted Horses", "The Hound", "Two Soldiers", Light in August, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Town
Description: The road that Stevens drives along to get from Jefferson to the site of the inquest on Lonnie Grinnup's body is described as "eight miles" long (70). Because Lonnie lives "almost in the exact center of the thousand and more acres his ancestors had once owned" (71), and the first of these ancestors was a "Grenier" (the original Old Frenchman, 70), we assume the road leads out of Jefferson to the southeast, where the hamlet of Frenchman's Bend sits near the river.

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "Appendix: Compson", Requiem for a Nun
Description: Long gone by the time of the story, the "Chickasaw Agency post" was the first white settlement in Yoknapatawpha, the origin of Jefferson (70). It was already there "a hundred years" ago - i.e. in the 1830s - when the first white pioneers arrived on the scene and "bought land in the Indian patent" (70).
When travelling to Parchman Mink sees the Delta for the first time, it's a "vast alluvial swamp of cypress and gum and brake" (53).

OtherTexts: "Centaur in Brass", The Town
Description: We know from The Town that after moving out of the tent behind the restaurant, Flem and Eula live in this bungalow, which he buys and remodels once he becomes vice-president of the bank. But while The Town provides a good many details about the residence, The Mansion provides no details at all. It does, however, use an intriguing phrase when it locates "Flem's house" on "that whole Snopes street" (161) - which seems to suggest that perhaps the various members of the clan who move into Jefferson over the years all come to live in one part of town.

OtherTexts: Flags in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, The Town
Description: In Flags in the Dust, this site by the side of the road is where old Bayard Sartoris suffers a fatal heart attack in the middle of a car accident; his grandson Bayard was driving, and the event leads him to exile himself from Yoknapatawpha. In The Mansion, by contrast, the event's significance is defined by the crisis it creates for the Sartoris Bank.

OtherTexts: "Centaur in Brass", "Knight's Gambit", "Spotted Horses", "Two Soldiers", "Uncle Willy", "Vendee", Absalom, Absalom!, As I Lay Dying, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Hamlet, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: This is where Flem and Eula go after their hasty marriage, to disguise the fact that Eula is already pregnant. In the fictions "Texas" is often the place that Yoknapatawphans who have misbehaved light out for.

OtherTexts: The Hamlet
Description: In The Mansion, Faulkner does not describe this location at all. It is simply the setting in which Mink Snopes touches his wife "that first time with amazement and reverence and incredulous excitement the night of his marriage" (100). In The Hamlet, by contrast, Faulkner provides rich detail of Mink's quest to find the sea and instead happening upon a "south Mississippi convict camp" (244) where he meets his future wife. In the previous novel, we included the "nearest county seat" where Mink gets married (264) in this location marker -- and for consistency across novels and maps, we have done the same for The Mansion.

OtherTexts: "Appendix: Compson", "Go Down, Moses", Go Down, Moses, Light in August, The Town
Description: Since we have to create a location for the place from which the narrator is writing or telling the story, we have chosen "Chicago." The narrator identifies himself as an "American" in the opening sentences (407), and not from the South, based on what he says about Bland: "He was a Southerner, too, like Sartoris" - but not, apparently, like him (408). Beyond that we cannot say where he is from, nor does the story give any clue about where he is living in the present, twelve years after the end of the War; it could be anywhere in the U.S. or indeed in Europe. "Chicago" in this case is meant simply to give us a place on a map, that is as probable as any other place for this unidentified American to have landed.

LocationTitle: Western Front Inset: Skies over France
OtherTexts: Flags in the Dust
Description: Sartoris and his brother are serving in different units in the Royal Air Force when the brother is shot down somewhere over the enemy lines. Sartoris spends a week "roosting about five thousand feet" above the troops on the ground until he finds and shoots down the "Hun patrol leader" who shot down his brother (414).
Monaghan's describes himself as "of the Irish nation" (420), the "son of an immigrant" who came "out of a peat bog" in Ireland and across the ocean to America (416).

LocationTitle: Western Front Inset: On the Road to Amiens
Description: This location includes both the road where the story begins - "in the car," "going to Amiens" (407) - and the specific spot "on the lonely road between two beet fields" where the car stops and the men in it are joined by Monaghan and "a second man" (410).

The subadar is from India, as are the troops serving with the English forces in the story he tells. The story he tells - especially the way the troops compare the "rifles" they are issued to "spears" which are "too short and too heavy" to "slay a swift enemy" (424) - makes "India" seem like a very primitive place. (Over one million Indian troops served in the various theaters of World War I.)
AuthOtherTexts: Flags in the Dust, The Town

OtherTexts: "Appendix: Compson", "Death Drag", "The Tall Men", "There Was a Queen", "Two Soldiers", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, The Mansion, The Town
Description: The subadar tells a story about his "people," the soldiers from India with whom he serves for a time on the front lines in the War (414). The story mentions both the allied "trench" in which the troops "squat, motionless" for days (424), and the German "trench" which the same troops charge and capture for several days (425). It also mentions a [bomb] "crater" in the space between the trenches (425), what was typically called No Man's Land during the War, but does not go into any further physical descriptions of the front.

Prussia, where the German pilot's family are "little barons" (417), is the large German state that dominated the nation's politics before and during the First World War. Berlin was its capital before it also became the county's capital in 1871.

Although the story spells it "Beyreuth," it's clear that it is referring to Bayreuth, Germany, where Richard Wagner composed and staged many of his famous operas - the "music" that the subadar and the German pilot share a passion for (413).

OtherTexts: "All the Dead Pilots"
Description: The RAF squadron that most of the story's characters serve in flies out of an airfield located somewhere behind the front, probably west of Amiens - though the text gives no clear clues about its location.

OtherTexts: "All the Dead Pilots"
Description: Most of the story takes place in Amiens, France. The area around the city saw heavy fighting in 1918, during Germany's last campaign of World War I, though the city itself was not captured. Located in Amiens are: the Cloche-Clos nightclub, "full of noise and smoke" and crowded with French soldiers and civilians celebrating the Armistice when the story's characters arrive (411); the nearby plaza, "empty" at night, so quiet that the narrator can "hear the faint water in the fountain" and "the sound of a band" playing somewhere in the distance (424); and also nearby, through an "arch" and up "an alley," a brothel (The literal translation of "Cloche-Clos" is "closed bell.")

OtherTexts: "Centaur in Brass", The Town
Description: Before the war, Monaghan attended Yale University, which is located in New Haven, Connecticut. His immigrant father speaks sarcastically about his "fine friends, the fathers and mothers and sisters of them you met at Yale" (415).

OtherTexts: "Appendix: Compson", "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", Flags in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury, The Town
Description: Monaghan is the son of an Irish immigrant who grows up in New York City. New York was where many of the Irish who fled the potato famine settled; by 1860 there were over 200,000 of them in the city, and by the end of the 19th century they were a dominant force in city politics.

OtherTexts: Flags in the Dust
Description: Bland attends Oxford University as a Rhodes Scholar, and while there he heard the subadar speak "before the Union" (409). The oldest university in the English-speaking world, Oxford is located in Oxford, England, which is also the home of the Oxford Union debating society, founded in 1823.

OtherTexts: "A Bear Hunt", "Delta Autumn", "Dry September", "Lion", "The Bear", "The Old People", "Wash", Absalom, Absalom!, Go Down, Moses, The Reivers , The Town
Description: "The hunting and fishing camp in the Tallahatchie River bottom" where General Compson dies is an important location in a number of Yoknapatawpha fictions (329). The General, in fact, is the fifth person (and the second former Confederate officer) who dies there, along with a dog named Lion.

This icon represents the sites of the various social events - including "high school parties and church socials" and the "parties on shadowy porticoes and summer lawns" - that Minnie Cooper attends with her "contemporaries" and "schoolmates" attend together (174). Presumably these gatherings occur mainly at the the young people's homes, but also at churches and perhaps at the school.

The "camp meeting" that Cora Tull refers to, where Whitfield "wrestled with [Addie's] spirit," is not described (166). Typically, however, in the South and other parts of rural America, a camp meeting was an annual retreat of church members, for the purposes of religious revival. Typically too, they take place in the woods or some other area at a distance from the congregation's daily lives, and last at least several days.

OtherTexts: "Centaur in Brass", "Mule in the Yard", Light in August
Description: Jason's "friend from Memphis" buys food every weekend "from the grocer's" (340).

OtherTexts: "Dry September", "Hair", "Knight's Gambit", "Pantaloon in Black", "Shall Not Perish", Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion, The Town
Description: "The local picture show" is shown at the town's one movie theater, which in other texts is located on the Square (340).

OtherTexts: "Mule in the Yard", The Reivers
Description: The "farmers' supply store" where Jason works is described as a "gloomy cavern which only men ever entered - a cavern cluttered and walled and stalagmitehung with plows and discs and loops of tracechain and singletrees and mulecollars and sidemeat and cheap shoes and horselinament and flour and molasses" (333). The narrative explains that the gloom has a racial source: "since those who supplied Mississippi farmers or at least Negro Mississippi farmers for a share of the crop" were anxious to sell their black customers only what they needed to make the crop, and so the store's merchandise was "hidden" from view (334). Jason himself, after selling what's left of his family's property in 1933, converts "a pair of offices" above this store "into a bedroom-kitchen-bath" in which he lives (339).

The county library is in Jefferson. The "Appendix" mentions several of the books on its shelves by name or at least by type: "Forever Amber" and "Jurgen and Tom Jones," and various "volumes of Thorne Smith" (333). With the exception of Fielding's Tom Jones, the 18th century English novel, these works are by 20th century American novelists who could be considered competitors of Faulkner's for the attention of the reading public; all of them were notorious for their representation of sex. Melissa Meek, the librarian, continually tries to keep this fare "out of the hands of high school juniors and seniors"; the other patrons who are mentioned are "matrons, wives of the bankers and doctors and lawyers," who check out and return these kinds of books "wrapped from view in sheets of Memphis and Jackson newspapers" (333).

OtherTexts: Absalom, Absalom!
Description: The son of General Compson, Jason III, keeps but no longer uses "an office upstairs above the Square" in Jefferson; "dusty filing-cases" in the office "entomb" many of "the oldest names in the county" (330). We assume the office is the same one his father had.

OtherTexts: Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury
Description: The Jefferson "golf club" originally builds a course on the land it buys from the Compsons (330), but during the 1930s it relocates the "golfcourse" to another part of the county (331). We have to speculate about its new location.

OtherTexts: "That Evening Sun", The Sound and the Fury
Description: The "one servant's cabin" where "Dilsey's family lives" is one of the last remaining pieces of Compson property in the late 1920s (330); it is presumably torn down when the entire property is transformed into a housing development.

OtherTexts: "A Justice", "A Name for the City", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Raid", "Retreat", "Skirmish at Sartoris", "That Evening Sun", Absalom, Absalom!, Go Down, Moses, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury, The Unvanquished
Description: In addition to the story of the Compson family, the "Appendix" tells the story of the place where they live. It begins as the "Compson Domain" (329): a "solid square mile" of "forested" land that the first Yoknapatawpha Compson acquires from the Chickasaw Indians in 1813 (328). "Twenty years later," it is a large cotton plantation, "with its slavequarters and stables and kitchengardens," "formal lawns and promenades and pavilions," and a "columned porticoed house" designed by an architect and furnished from France (328). The place goes into decline after the Civil War, until by the 20th century "what was left" of the property, "now known merely as the Compson place," consists of "the weedchoked traces of the old ruined lawns and promenades, the house which had needed painting too long already, [and] the scaling columns of the portico" (329-30). In the 1920s it is called "the old Compson place," even though still occupied by Compsons; they sell the last major piece of the land "to a golfclub" (330). In the 1930s the house itself is sold "to a countryman who operated it as a boarding-house" (331). Not long after that the house is torn down and "the old square mile" of land turned into a housing development: "row after row of small crowded jerrybuilt individuallyowned demiurban bungalows" (331). We represent this Location on the map as a 'mansion,' which it is between the early 1800s and 1940 or so, but in the "Appendix" the place begins as primordial wilderness and ends as a modern development.

Description: Frony lives here after her marriage.
