Description: The Mississippi State Insane Asylum - referred to in the text as the "the State Asylum in Jackson" (331) - was located in that city, the state capital, until 1935.

OtherTexts: "An Error in Chemistry", "Dry September", "Elly", "Gold Is Not Always", "Hair", "Hand Upon the Waters", "Knight's Gambit", "Lion", "Miss Zilphia Gant", "Monk", "Mule in the Yard", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Raid", "Retreat", "Shall Not Perish", "Smoke", "That Evening Sun", "That Will Be Fine", "The Tall Men", "The Unvanquished", "There Was a Queen", "Two Soldiers", "Uncle Willy", "Vendee", Absalom, Absalom!, Flags in the Dust, Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Reivers , The Sound and the Fury, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: The real city of Memphis, Tennessee, is the closest city to Faulkner's fictional Yoknapatawpha, and it occurs frequently in his fiction. The "Appendix" mentions four different places in the city. "The Negro residence section" of Memphis is where Dilsey lives in the 1940s (336), and "Memphis's Beale Street," where Dilsey's son "TP" is depicted at the end, was well-known by the early 20th century for its nightlife (343). When Melissa Meek travels from Jefferson to Memphis, she arrives and departs from the "bus terminal" (337). Memphis is also the site of the business school where Jason Compson IV learns to be a cotton broker (339); the female "friend" who stays with him in Jefferson on weekends after his mother dies is "from Memphis" too (340).

Cannebiere is the name of a historic street in the old quarter of Marseilles, France. By "a Cannebiere backdrop," the narrative probably refers not just to the "mountains" and the "sea," but also to the elegant life found there during the district's heyday between the two World Wars, when its cafes and hotels and boutiques were frequently by members of high society (334).

OtherTexts: "Ambuscade", "Raid", Absalom, Absalom!, Requiem for a Nun, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: Resaca, a town in northwestern Georgia, was the site of a three-day battle in May, 1864, during the Union Army's campaign to capture Atlanta.

OtherTexts: "Ambuscade", "Raid", "Skirmish at Sartoris", Absalom, Absalom!, The Unvanquished
Description: Located in southwestern Tennessee, Shiloh was the location of a major Civil War battle on April 6-7, 1862. On the second day it turned into a Confederate defeat, though there's no indication of how General Compson himself "failed" there (329).

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", Requiem for a Nun
Description: Jason Compson travels to Yoknapatawpha from Kentucky along the "Natchez Trace" (328), a 440-mile trail originally created by the Indians between the sites of Nashville, Tennessee, and Natchez, Mississippi. It linked three rivers - the Cumberland, the Tennessee and the Mississippi - and passed through northeast Mississippi. In 18th and early 19th centures, it served as a major overland route for traders and settlers.

OtherTexts: "A Justice", "Hair", "Knight's Gambit", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Race at Morning", "Red Leaves", "The Old People", Absalom, Absalom!, Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Mansion, The Reivers , The Town
Description: The imported furniture in the original Compson mansion travels "by steamboat from France and New Orleans" (328).

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", "Red Leaves", Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary
Description: Much of the furniture inside the original Compson mansion was imported from France (328). Caddy Compson's last known address is also in France: she "vanished in Paris with the German occupation, 1940," during World War II (332); historically, the German army occupied Paris on 14 June 1940.

OtherTexts: Absalom, Absalom!, Requiem for a Nun
Description: "The whole Mississippi Valley" (327) is the immense area drained by the Mississippi River and its tributaries. Until 1803 much of this territory was claimed by Spain, which ceded it to France, which sold it to the U.S. as the Louisiana Purchase.

OtherTexts: "Fool About a Horse", The Reivers , The Sound and the Fury
Description: "Harrodsburg" (327) is the modern name of the town in north central Kentucky that was originally settled by James Harrod in 1774 and called Harrodstown. It is often referred to as the oldest permanent American settlement west of Appalachians. It is also, as the "Appendix" suggests, close to Boonesborough (326).

Charles Stuart Compson vanishes "from one of Tarleton's regiments on a Georgia battlefield" in 1778 (326). It's not clear what battlefield Faulkner has in mind; there was fighting in Georgia during Revolutionary War, but Tarleton not involved in any of it.

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "Hand Upon the Waters", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Skirmish at Sartoris", "The Unvanquished", Absalom, Absalom!, Requiem for a Nun, The Reivers , The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: After fleeing Scotland, Quentin Compson lived in "Carolina" (326). Faulkner's narrative does not say which Carolina - which is also the case with those other Yoknapatawpha families from "Carolina," the Sartorises and the McCaslins - but the most likely one is South Carolina, on account of the major port of Charleston.

OtherTexts: Intruder in the Dust, The Town
Description: The Compson family, like much of the white population of Yoknapatawpha, is originally from Scotland. The story mentions three different places in that country, all of them real: Glasgow is the home of the printer who was Quentin MacLachan's father; Perth is city in central Scotland where Quentin's mother's family lived and where he was brought up after death of both parents; and "Culloden Moor" is where the Jacobites (including Quentin) were decisively defeated in a battle with Great Britain in 1746.

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "By the People", "Knight's Gambit", "Retreat", "Skirmish at Sartoris", "There Was a Queen", "Two Soldiers", Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Sound and the Fury, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: "Wassi Town" is undoubtedly the way Faulkner (or rather, the Chickasaw Indians in the story) refer to Washington, D.C. - and the "gold tepee" where the "Great White Father" lives is Andrew Jackson's White House (326).

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "Hand Upon the Waters", Requiem for a Nun
Description: The government Agent to the Chickasaw tribe operates from a "long rambling onestorey mud-chinked building" that includes a "tradingpost store" (325). The "Agency" is already there where the first Compson in Mississippi arrives in 1811. In both this story and the later Requiem for a Nun (1950), it is described as the beginning of "Jefferson Mississippi" (325), but the "Appendix" does not provide any clear way to locate it in relation to the boundaries of the eventual town. Later in this story he refers to it as "the Chickasaw Agency at Okatoba (which in 1860 was still called Old Jefferson)" (328). In two contemporaneous texts ("Hand upon the Waters" [1939] and Intruder in the Dust [1948]), "Okatoba" is the name of the county immediately south of Yoknapatawpha - but putting the agency there would put it, and the origins of Jefferson, entirely out of Yoknapatawpha. On the other hand, Requiem for a Nun, written five years after the "Appendix," is explicit about how the Jefferson Indian agency "postoffice-tradingpost-store" stood just north of the site of the courthouse and the square, and that is the basis for the place we give the agency on the map.

Uncle Rodney's most recent married paramour lives here with her husband, and Rodney sends Georgie there to tell her the time and place of their rendezvous and to remind her to bring "all the jewelry" with her (282). Georgie notices that "the house was dark all right" and that there are "two magnolia trees" in the yard (282, 282). Although the story does not explicitly say who lives in this house, it is probably either the Tuckers or the Pruitts. Rodney has had or is having affairs with the women of both these marriages. We feel it's most likely that the house is where Mrs. Pruitt lives.

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Hamlet, The Town
Description: In the Choctaw language, "Oklahoma" means "red people." It was the land to which many of the Indians tribes were sent by the American government during the first half of the 19th century, including the Chickasaws who once lived in Yoknapatawpha. When Faulkner says they were granted the land by treaty because the U.S. did not know then "about the oil" (325), he may be thinking specifically of the gusher that erupted in Oklahoma in 1896, leading to another rush, not for farm land as in 1889 but for oil rich land. New technologies like the automobile were making oil a very valuable commodity.

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", "Lion", Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion, The Town
Description: During the 20th century it was much easier to obtain a divorce in Mexico than in most U.S. states, which is no doubt why Caddy divorced her second husband there in 1925.

OtherTexts: The Mansion
Description: "Hollywood," where Caddy meets her second husband (and where Faulkner often worked as a screenwriter during the 1930s and 40s but where he never felt at home), has been the center of the American movie industry since the 1920s.

OtherTexts: The Sound and the Fury
Description: French Lick, where Caddy meets her first husband, is a town in southern Indiana. Since before the Civil War it has been well-known as a resort community with hotels and spas built up around its sulfur springs.

OtherTexts: The Mansion
Description: Until 1824, Spain was a major colonial power in the territories that became part of the U.S. Until 1803, it claimed much of the "Mississippi Valley" (327), the immense area drained by the Mississippi River and its tributaries also known as the Louisiana Purchase, which the U.S. acquired after Spain ceded it to France.

OtherTexts: "Elly", "Hair", "Knight's Gambit", Absalom, Absalom!, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury, The Town
Description: Quentin goes to Cambridge, Massachusetts, to attend Harvard College. When the "Appendix" says that he "waited first to complete" his freshman year before committing suicide (331), Faulkner revises the story he told in The Sound and the Fury.

This icon represents the many cities and "country towns" where the man who calls himself Joel Flint performed in, first for twenty years as "Signor Casonova the Great," then for perhaps another half dozen years as carnival "bandsman, ringman, Bornean wild man" and pitchman (134). How much of the U.S. he covered during that time can only be guessed at.

OtherTexts: "By the People", "Centaur in Brass", "Fool About a Horse", "Hand Upon the Waters", "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", "Miss Zilphia Gant", "Spotted Horses", "The Hound", "Tomorrow", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Town
Description: Wesley Pritchel and the Flints live near a "little cross-roads hamlet" (114) that is about "twenty-odd miles" from Jefferson (113). Except for the distance from town, the story gives no indication of where in Yoknapatawpha this "hamlet" can be found, so in the absence of better evidence we are assuming this hamlet is Frenchman's Bend, The Hamlet in the novel of that name and a place to which Faulkner's imagination repeatedly returned. And on that basis, we assume the most likely setting for Joel Flint's "derogations" of the "local southern custom" of drinking toddies is the cross-roads store at the center of the Bend (114): that porch is a frequent gathering place for the men in the Bend.

OtherTexts: As I Lay Dying
Description: There is a real Mount Vernon in northeast Mississippi. Measured from Oxford, the original of Jefferson, it is eighteen miles to the southeast. In Flags in the Dust it is referred to as a "hamlet" "six miles away" from the MacCallum place, where the "young woman" whom Lee MacCallum is courting lives (350-51).

Bayard, Buddy and Richard capture a possum "just behind the spring house" (338). In the era before indoor plumbing, houses were often supplied with water from a nearby spring, and it was not uncommon (though it was a sign of wealth and possession) to erect a small outbuilding over the spring, to keep it from filling with leaves and branches or being used by animals. This building also often served as a primitive kind of refrigerator, a cool place to store perishables.

This "glade" is described as "an old field, sedge-grown, its plow-scars long healed over" (330). This is one of the signs that the MacCallum property was once a farm or plantation. There are apparently still some Negro tenants farming part of the property - i.e. the "two negro men" Bayard sees in the kitchen on his first evening at the place (336) - but on the whole, like this field, the MacCallum property seems to be reverting to nature, and used more for hunting and making moonshine, perhaps also breeding domestic animals, than for growing cotton or other commercial crops.

The kitchen where Mandy cooks and the MacCallums eat is, as is the case in many of the larger houses in Jefferson and Yoknapatawpha, in "a separate building" from the main house (336). This common southern design feature - a detached or semi-detached kitchen - helped keep the heat and odor of cooking out of the 'big house' and served as a low-tech form of fire prevention: if the kitchen caught fire it was less likely to burn the whole house down. At the same time this arrangement provided the white family's black servants with a place indoors where they could meet - as when Bayard first enters this kitchen and finds "two negro men and a half-grown boy" sitting "behind the stove," talking with Mandy, 336). What is anomalous about the arrangement at the MacCallums is the fact that the white family eats in the kitchen too, rather than in a dining room in the main house; this is one way the novel distinguishes the yeoman MacCallums from aristocratic families like the Sartorises and Benbows. There is a "disused shed behind the kitchen" which Buddy uses as a kennel for the possums he captures (338).

LocationTitle: Hunting Grounds at the MacCallum Place
Description: Bayard goes out hunting with Buddy MacCallum in three different environments: "skeletoned fields," and "stagnant backwaters along the river," and "the [river] bottom" itself; they are after different game in the different locations - "birds," or "duck and geese," or "'coon and wildcat," respectively (351).

"Miz Winterbottom's" is where the two Yankee "cyarpet-baggers" who try to organize the emancipated slaves to vote are boarding, and it is here that Colonel Sartoris seeks them out and kills them - before apologizing to Mrs. Winterbottom for "mussing up [her] guest-room" with the murder (243). (Faulkner narrates this shooting in two later novels - Light in August and The Unvanquished; in that last account he relocates it in the Holston House, the oldest hotel in Jefferson.)

OtherTexts: "Skirmish at Sartoris", "The Unvanquished", Absalom, Absalom!, Requiem for a Nun, The Hamlet, The Unvanquished
Description: Fort Moultrie was built on Sullivan's Island as part of the coastal defenses for Charleston, South Carolina. It "fell" (11) when Confederate militia occupied it after its small Federal garrison evacuated on 26 December 1860 - about three months before the Confederates attacked the nearby Fort Sumter, which is usually cited as the beginning of the Civil War.

OtherTexts: Absalom, Absalom!, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Town
Description: The "archaeologists" who try to explore the "Indian and even aboriginal relics" that are preserved in the clay-pit on Pritchel's land are "from the State University" (119). It seems likely that Faulkner is referring to the University of Mississippi, located in his own home town of Oxford.

LocationTitle: Scene of Car Accident in Beyond
Description: This icon represents the place where the "young man" who waits by the gate in Beyond died when he swerved his car to avoid hitting the child who "ran into the road" (784). The few details he provides about the accident give no clues as to its location, and other than the fact that he speaks English, the young man gives no clues about where he's from, so we have chosen to put the icon in the middle of the U.S.

OtherTexts: "Death Drag", "The Unvanquished", Light in August, The Sound and the Fury, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: On the way from Jefferson to Mottstown, George stops the carriage "at a branch" that crosses the road in order to soak a handkerchief so that his wife had wipe Aunt Louisa's face (272). ("Branch" is the local term for a creek or small stream.)

Grandpa's cook, Mandy, lives in a cabin "in the back yard" of the big house where her white employer lives (274). The narrator calls it both "Mandy's cabin" and "Mandy's house" (274, 276), but it seems likely that Grandpa owns it. It may have been a slave cabin in the past, like other backyard cabins in the Yoknapatawpha fictions, but the story does not explicitly say that. When Rodney is locked inside it, we learn that it has a "door" and at least two "windows" (276).
All we know about "Mrs. Jordon's"- the Mottstown house where Georgie is sent to spend Christmas Eve - is that it has "a persimmon tree" in the front yard (287).

This house is the home of the married woman in Jefferson with whom Rodney conducts "business" - i.e. has an affair - during his visit to town "last summer" (268). He pays Georgie a nickel to look out for Mr. Tucker during these assignations.

Trains travel directly between Jefferson and Mottstown (like the one that Rosie takes, 276), but to travel from either town to Memphis one has to switch trains, which explains why in this story Rodney "hires a rig" and travels to Kingston, where the "fast train to Memphis" runs on "the main line" (279). (There is a real Kingston in Mississippi, but it is in the southwest corner of the state, hundreds of miles out of the Rodney's way. Faulkner's "Kingston" is a fictional place, perhaps the same fictional place as "Kinston," the town that Horace Benbow moves to at the end of Flags in the Dust and runs away from at the start of Sanctuary.)

Description: Founded in 1819, Memphis, Tennessee, is the closest big city to Jefferson, and it plays a role in many of Faulkner's novels and stories. It often figures as the place where the people of Yoknapatawpha go to misbehave in one way or another. That is presumably Rodney's errand when he takes "the fast train to Memphis" from Kingston, although beyond noting how alarmed "papa" and Uncle Fred are when they learn about the trip, the text provides no details (279).

Georgie's grandpa lives in Mottstown, a small town featured in several of Faulkner's fictions. Every Christmas, Georgie's family, including their black cook, visits Grandpa. There is no way to tell from the text how large the house itself is. It seems like a large structure capable of accommodating three generations of the family: besides Georgie and his parents on their visit, Grandpa's grown children, Rodney and Louisa, live there - Louisa with her husband and children. Grandpa himself seems to have lived there for many years. The property includes the "woodshed" or "woodhouse" from which Uncle Fred gets a padlock (276), and the cabin in the back yard where Grandpa's cook, Mandy, lives.

The Allison home has housed first the Judge as a boy and a single man, then the Judge and his wife, then the two of them and their son, and the Judge's mother and aunts lived there as well when the Judge was a boy. It is well-kept, tended by two black servants, a housekeeper and a groundskeeper; the furniture is old-fashioned but comfortable and well-made. It is the sort of home that befits "a Republican judge in a Democratic stronghold" (789).

OtherTexts: "Centaur in Brass", "Hand Upon the Waters", "Knight's Gambit", "The Unvanquished", As I Lay Dying, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, The Sound and the Fury, The Unvanquished
Description: Mottstown - or as Faulkner sometimes spells it, Mottson - is the seat of the county on Yoknapatawpha's southern border. It appears frequently in Faulkner's fiction, though this is the only story centered there. As Georgie and his family arrive in the town, they "come down the last hill and into the valley where Mottstown was" (273). Georgie notes the "holly wreaths in the windows" of the houses in town, "like at home in Jefferson" (274). Also in town are the "pool hall" where Grandpa thinks Rodney can be found (279), the "stable" "up the lane" from which Rodney steals a horse and buggy (282), and the Compress Association office where Rodney works. (Cotton compression is a means to pack cotton into tighter bales for shipment than bales packed in a cotton gin. A compress association, such as the one for which Rodney works, would have been dedicated to advocating for certain standards and practices in this process.)
Other Structure: Town; Mansion; Poolhall; Livery Stable; Civic Office

Description: Georgie lives with his mother and father in a comfortable middle-class neighborhood. Although the family has a black servant named Rosie, it's unclear whether she lives on the property, as his grandfather's cook does.

OtherTexts: Absalom, Absalom!, Flags in the Dust, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Reivers , The Sound and the Fury, The Town
Description: Georgie's father runs the livery stable, which has at least one other employee, whose name is John Paul.

OtherTexts: "Dry September", "That Evening Sun", As I Lay Dying, Sanctuary
Description: When Louisa comes from Mottstown to Jefferson, "papa" takes her to this hotel "to eat breakfast" (269). The story stops here only briefly, when Georgie's family picks up his father and Louisa on the way to Grandpa's (270). (Jefferson's main hotel is the Holston House, which often appears in the Yoknapatawpha fictions, but the hotel in this story is never identified by name.)

OtherTexts: Absalom, Absalom!
Description: Whether this is an actual place or just a landscape that exists in the judge's imagination, Beyond has certain distinct features. It has a "narrow entrance" (795) through which arrivals crowd and at which some people seem to linger in wait for others to arrive. Inhabitants seem to be able to wander there at will, and it has features of a conventional earthly landscape: a bench, for example, "inside a park" (788) where a child plays in the dust with his toys (792) and a boy named Howard "rides past every day on his pony" (794). Beyond seems like a non-denominational purgatory, if not heaven; but it contains people who have killed themselves, who carry weapons, who have money and tobacco, and who have servants, as well as middle-class and poorer folks. It is possible to leave Beyond, as the judge does, but everyone he meets seems to be content to remain there, even characters who on Earth doubted or denied the existence of an afterlife. (It's impossible to locate "Beyond" on any of our maps, so our decision to place it somewhere above the "WORLD" is best understood as an expedient, not a geo-theological assertion.)

Judge Allison's office is on the Square and, like many other Jefferson offices, up one flight of "stairs" from the street; it is opposite the courthouse: when he descends those stairs, he can read the courthouse clock (795).

Description: After he returns from Beyond, Judge Allison visits the cemetery, where he sees the grave of his son alongside a "raw and recent excavation" (796).

Description: Courthouse Square sits at the center of Jefferson, and at the center of Yoknapatawpha, and also at the center of many of Faulkner's fictions. The courthouse itself, which sits at the center of the Square, is where Judge Allison conducts trials during his years as a federal judge. He has an office across the street from it; on his way back from Beyond, he "look[s] up at the clock on the courthouse, as he never failed to do on descending his office stairs" (795).

Description: One of Jefferson's oldest businesses, Christian's drugstore is owned by Willy Christian, the grandson of the original owner. Inside the store is a "prescription case where Uncle Willy kept the medicines" (162). He kept the "morphine in a little flimsy wooden drawer that anybody with a screwdriver or a knife blade or maybe just a hair pin could prize open, even though it did have a key to it that Uncle Willy kept hidden under a gallon jug marked Nux Vomica on a dark shelf that nobody but him was even supposed to bother because it was so dark back there" (163-64). Christian's is also a soda shop that serves ice cream (for free to the boys' baseball teams) and has tables for customers, a magazine rack and a perfume counter (198). (Christian's drugstore in "Uncle Willy" has a separate entry, for reasons that are explained in that entry.)

Description: For most of Yoknapatawpha's history, the Jefferson railroad station serves as the portal by which people come to and go out of the county. In this novel it is most important as the pass-through point for Byron Snopes' half-Apache children - they arrive at the station addressed to Flem Snopes, and depart through it when the town sends them back to El Paso.

LocationTitle: Houses and Cabins Lonnie Grinnup Visits
Description: Lonnie Grinnup and Joe periodically shut up Lonnie's shack and visit acquaintances who live in these "houses or cabins ten and fifteen miles away" (71). Lonnie and Joe sometimes sleep "in the hay of lofts," which suggests at least some of the people they stay with are farmers, but in other places "his hosts" let them sleep "in beds in family or company rooms" (71), making it harder to determine whether to identify these locations with "houses" or "cabins," and impossible to say for sure where to put them on the map. They could be in various parts of the county, making our choices in this case particularly speculative.

Description: Founded in 1819, Memphis, Tennessee, is the closest big city to Yoknapatawpha County, and it plays a role in many of Faulkner's novels and stories. Memphis is most frequently associated with the kinds of misbehavior and vice that are unavailable in Yoknapatawpha. It appears in this story as the place where a Yoknapatawpha man, Boyd Ballenbaugh, gets involved in several urban activities that imply violence and lawlessness: he is an "armed guard" during a textile strike, and then, with a set of "associates" from whom he later has to hide, in some kind of "business" that would attract the attention of "the police" (76).

OtherTexts: "An Error in Chemistry", "By the People", "Knight's Gambit", "Tomorrow", Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion, The Town
Description: After Gavin is shot, he is resting on the veranda of his home. This is presumably the home that Stevens shares with his married sister and her family in The Town and eight other Faulkner texts, and which is owned by their father. Here is the way Gavin's nephew, Charles Mallison, explains the arrangement in The Town: "We were all living with Grandfather then. I mean Grandfather was still alive then and he and Uncle Gavin had one side of the house, Grandfather in his bedroom and what we called the office downstairs, and Uncle Gavin on the same side upstairs, where he had built an outside stairway so he could go and come from the side yard, and Mother and Father and Cousin Gowan on the other side."

Located past the store and a quarter of a mile to the right of the turn for Lonnie Grinnup's cabin, this cabin is where Nate lives with his wife. When Gavin Stevens arrives there on his way to Lonnie Grinnup's camp, it is too "dark" to see anything but its "littered yard" (79).

Description: The house where Ballenbaugh lives is "just across the river" and three miles from Okatoba County (78).

Description: "Located in the V of the fork" of the dirt lane road that leads "back toward the hills" and at the top of a rise stands the church, "white-painted and steepleless" (75). Beside it is the graveyard where Lonnie Grinnup is buried. The text does not say what the denomination of this church is, but it is certainly one of Yoknapatawpha's main rural Protestant faiths - Baptist or Methodist or Presbyterian.

Description: Jefferson is the county seat for Yoknapatawpha County. Historically, Louis Grenier and the other founding fathers of the county arrived "on horseback, through the Cumberland Gap from the Carolinas, where Jefferson was still a Chickasaw Agency post" (70).

A mill that turns grain into flour, the grist mill is located beside the store in "Hand Upon the Waters" and is where the inquest into Lonnie Grinnup's death occurs: "before the open door of which the clean Saturday overalls and shirts and the bared heads and the sunburned necks striped with the white razor lines of Saturday neck shaves were densest and quietest" (72). This commercial space that is turned into a public courtroom - much like the two country stores in "Barn Burning" that also become makeshift courtrooms - speaks to the grist mill's importance within the community: "There was a table and three chairs where the coroner and two witnesses sat" (72).

Description: Located "across the long flat where the highway began to parallel the river bottom," the store is described in this story as bustling with activity as a result of the inquest into Lonnie Grinnup's death: "ordinarily it would have been deserted, but now he could already see clotted about it the topless and battered cars, the saddled horses and mules and the wagons" (72).

Description:
Mr. Compson's letter just says that Rosa Coldfield "was buried" (141) - it doesn't say where. There is a family cemetery at Sutpen's Hundred, but
given the fact that Rosa puts Judith's grave as far from Sutpen's as that graveyard allows, it seems extremely unlikely that she herself would be buried there. We assume therefore that Rosa's grave is in the town cemetery that appears in so many other Yoknapatawpha fictions.

Description: Tyler Ballenbaugh purchases life insurance for Lonnie Grinnup in Mottstown. "Mottstown" (which Faulkner sometimes spells Mottson) is the seat of Okatoba County, "just across the river" to the south of Yoknapatawpha (78). It is located on Faulkner's map in Absalom, Absalom! by an arrow pointing south of Jefferson and the notation "To Mottstown, where Jason Compson lost his niece's trail, and where Anse Bundren and his boys had to go in order to reach Jefferson." Okatoba County in "Hand Upon the Waters" appears to be the site of commerce for Yoknapatawpha residents who are wary of economic institutions: "Stevens knew of more than Ballenbaugh who owned land in one county and bought their cars and trucks and banked their money in another, obeying the country-bred man's inherent, possibly atavistic, faint distrust, perhaps, not of men in white collars but of paving and electricity" (78).

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", Absalom, Absalom!, Requiem for a Nun, The Reivers
Description: Along with other families who founded Jefferson and Yoknapatawpha County, Lonnie Grinnup's family came to the area "through the Cumberland Gap from the Carolinas" (70). This Gap is a narrow pass through the Cumberland Mountains near the intersection of the states of Kentucky, Virginia, and Tennessee.

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "Appendix: Compson", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Skirmish at Sartoris", "The Unvanquished", Absalom, Absalom!, Requiem for a Nun, The Reivers , The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: Along with other families who founded Jefferson and Yoknapatawpha County, Lonnie Grinnup's family came to the area "through the Cumberland Gap from the Carolinas" (70).

A trot line is a long rope or cord with many separate lines of fishhooks attached to it, used for catching large quantities of fish, primarily catfish. Lonnie Grinnup's trotline "of light cotton rope" runs the width of the river (68) near his hut, and around the house are "short lengths of cord just cut from a spool near by, and a rusted can of full of heavy fishhooks, some of which had already been bent onto the cords" (68) that are ready to be baited and attached to the rope.

OtherTexts: Intruder in the Dust, The Reivers
Description: Located "in almost the exact center of the thousand and more acres his ancestors once owned" (71), Lonnie Grinnup's hut demonstrates the decay of the lineage of Louis Grenier, a wealthy planter who was one of the three founders of Yoknapatawpha County: Lonnie's home is "a conical hut with a pointed roof, built partly of mildewed canvas and odd-shaped boards and partly of oil tins hammered out flat. A rusted stovepipe projected crazily above it, there was a meager woodpile and an ax, and a bunch of cane poles leaned against it" (67-68).
A path that runs "between the river and the dense wall of cypress and cane and gum and brier" leading to Lonnie Grinnup's trotline and hut (67).

OtherTexts: "Ambuscade", "Appendix: Compson", "Raid", Requiem for a Nun, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: This location represents the battles that the Confederate Army of the West fights and loses as it retreats through Tennessee, "across Alabama into Georgia" (276) during 1864 and 1865.
This is where Bon's horse was found after his death, "trying to force the crib door" in the stable of a farm "four miles away" from Sutpen's (123).

OtherTexts: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Retreat", "The Tall Men", Flags in the Dust, Go Down, Moses, The Unvanquished
Description: Northern Virginia was the scene of a great many battles during the Civil War, including two at "Manassas" - the name by which Southerners referred to the battles of Bull Run (as the Union Army identified them); but "Pickett's charge" was in Pennsylvania, at "Gettysburg," as Quentin notes when he corrects Shreve's mistake (289). The regiment that Sartoris and Sutpen raise fights in the Civil War as part of Robert E. Lee's Army of Northern Virginia, although near the end of the War the unit is among the troops that Lee detaches to reinforce the Army of the West as it retreats through the Carolinas.

LocationTitle: Route between Yoknapatawpha and Mississippi River
Description: Each time Bon leaves Sutpen's Hundred to return to New Orleans, he first has to travel overland to the Mississippi River, where he boards a steamboat for the rest of the trip.
The "negro ball" where Charles Etienne Saint-Valery Bon starts a fight takes place in "a cabin a few miles from Sutpen's Hundred" (164).

Although Quentin most often refers to it generically as the "West Indies" (192) and Shreve flippantly refers to it as "Porto Rico or Haiti or wherever it was" (239), the place to which Sutpen goes to accomplish the first step in his design is the island of Haiti, as the Chronology and the Genealogy at the end of the novel make clear. The "Haiti" in the novel is not the historical Haiti, which successfully won independence from France and abolished slavery by 1804; at least, it still seems to be a slave-holding French colony when Sutpen arrives there in 1820, and in the novel the slave rebellion occurs in the late 1820s. Instead, Absalom! represents "Haiti" in vague and essentially symbolic terms. The 14-year-old Sutpen who goes there imagines it as a land of opportunity, "a place called the West Indies to which poor men went in ships and became rich" (195). The one long description of the "little lost island," furnished in Quentin's narrative but based on what his "Grandfather said," locates it in a moral realm rather than in the Caribbean or in history: as "the halfway point between what we call the jungle and what we call civilization," as "a spot of earth which might have been created and set aside by Heaven itself, Grandfather said, as a theatre for violence and injustice and bloodshed and all the satanic lusts of human greed and cruelty" (202). In terms of the story, the most important Haitian setting is the French sugar plantation where Sutpen is an overseer until the slaves revolt. It is in Haiti that Sutpen marries his first wife and has his first child, and where he acquires the twenty slaves he brings with him to Yoknapatawpha.

Quentin Compson assumes the first Sutpen to arrive in the new world traveled on a "ship from the Old Bailey" (180). The Old Bailey in London has been the site of the Central Criminal Court of England and Wales since the 16th century. A great many of North America's early colonists had been convicted of crimes in England, and were shipped out of the country as part of their sentence, but the idea that Sutpen's ancestors were transported criminals seems to be entirely Quentin's.

The Coldfield family is originally from Virginia (11), and "Richmond" is one of the cultural capitals of the Old South (188), but the most significant "Virginia" in the novel is the "nest of Tidewater plantations" (195) located in the "slack lowlands about the mouth of the James River" (178). This location includes "Jamestown," the British colony where "the first Sutpen" in the new world landed (180). It is also the place where Thomas Sutpen discovers and loses what the novel calls his "innocence" (178). It is imagined as the antithesis of the egalitarian and still largely natural world where Sutpen was born: it is "a country all divided and fixed and neat with a people living on it all divided and fixed and neat because of what color their skins happened to be and what they happened to own" (179). The most significant places in this place are the cabin where he and his family live, with its "rough partly rotten log walls" and "sagging roof" (190); the big house "two miles away," home of the planter for whom his father works, "the biggest house he had ever seen" (184); the quarters where this man's slaves live, with "their sound roofs and white wash," and the nearby commissary (185); the school which he attends "for about three months one winter" (194); and the hiding place to which he retreats after being ordered away from the front door of the big house - "a place where a game trail entered a cane brake and an oak tree had fallen across it and made a kind of cave" (188).
Other Structure: Plantation; White-occupied Cabin; Mansion; Quarters; Garden|Arbor; School; Woods|Wilderness

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "Knight's Gambit", "The Tall Men", Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury, The Town
Description: The novel's account of the way the Sutpen family "fell" from the mountains in western Virginia (180) to "the slack lowlands about the mouth of the James River" (181) is deliberately vague. They travel in "a lop-sided two wheeled cart" pulled by "two spavined oxen" (181), and the journey takes long enough for one of the family's daughters to have one child and become pregnant again with another. Along the way, the children repeatedly "sit in the cart outside the doors of doggeries and taverns" while the father gets drunk; the "huge bull of a nigger" who throws Mr. Sutpen out of one of these places is "the first black man, slave," Thomas ever sees (182). One time they stay in "a cowshed where the sister's [first] baby is born" (183). As the land begins to "flatten out . . . with good roads and fields," the "doggeries and taverns" become "hamlets," the "hamlets" become "villages," the "villages" become "towns" (182).

Thomas Sutpen was born in the mountains of western Virginia. By 1863 that would be "West Virginia," as Quentin calls it, but as Shreve reminds him, "West Virginia" didn't exist as a separate entity until 1861, when the people in that region seceded from Virginia after Virginia seceded from the Union, and didn't exist as a state until 1863, when it was admitted to the U.S. (179). The narrative's depiction of Sutpen's birthplace relies on a set of simplifications that sharply distinguish it as a rugged frontier from the older, more socially stratified slave-holding regions of the South. In the mountains, "the only colored people are Indians," "the land belongs to anybody and everybody," nobody owns more "objects" than anybody else (179) - and everyone lives in democratically similar cabins that "didn't have back doors" to which a ragged boy could be sent around to (188).

OtherTexts: "Beyond"
Description: We don't really have a place on any map for "Heaven," but just as The Hamlet contains a scene in "Hell," Absalom! includes the posthumous reunion that Mr. Compson imagines between Wash and Sutpen in an unnamed place that is clearly heaven: a place "serene, pleasant, unmarked by time or change of weather," and even with a new "scuppernong" arbor in which they can sit (152).

OtherTexts: "Ambuscade", "Appendix: Compson", "Raid", "Skirmish at Sartoris", The Unvanquished
Description: Shiloh, located in southwestern Tennessee, was the location of a major battle during the Civil War. The novel also calls it "Pittsburg Landing" (217), the name by which it was known in the South. The fighting took place on April 6-7th, 1862; by the end of "the second day and the lost battle" (275), casualties on both sides totaled 23,746. General Compson lost an arm there, and in one of the novel's many unresolved narrative questions, either Henry helped save the wounded Bon (217), or Bon rescued the wounded Henry (275). Other battles from the War's western theater mentioned in the novel are "Chikamauga and Franklin, Vicksburg and Corinth and Atlanta"; the first and last are in Georgia, the second and fourth are in Tennessee, and Vicksburg is in Mississippi; all, according to the narrative, were Union victories, or rather "names of lost battles" (276).

OtherTexts: "Ambuscade", "Hair", "Knight's Gambit", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Vendee", Go Down, Moses, Requiem for a Nun, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Unvanquished
Description: Goodhue Coldfield's father is from Tennessee, and it was presumably from there that he moved to Yoknapatawpha.

OtherTexts: Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust
Description: Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, was the site of the Civil War's bloodiest battle, fought over the three days July 1–3, 1863. "Pickett's charge" (289) on the final day resulted in 6500 men being killed or wounded in about an hour. ("Manassas," where Shreve mistakenly thinks Pickett's charge occurred, is the town in Virginia near the fields where two different battles, First and Second Bull Run, were fought, 289). The Confederate regiment from Yoknapatawpha that Sutpen commands in 1863 is supposed to have been "present at Gettysburg" (154).

OtherTexts: "Red Leaves", "That Evening Sun", "Vendee", Light in August, The Hamlet, The Reivers , The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: "Missouri" is one of the places in which the lawyer claims to be looking for Thomas Sutpen (244), and "Saint Louis" - usually spelled St. Louis, Missouri - is one of the places Ellen thinks Thomas Sutpen may have gone "on business" when Bon comes to Sutpen's Hundred the second time (263). Missouri was admitted to the U.S. as a slave state in 1831; in 1860 the population of St. Louis was over 160,000, making it the largest city on the Mississippi River.

OtherTexts: Light in August
Description: California is briefly mentioned twice in the novel, first speculatively, as one of the places Henry Sutpen might have fled after killing Bon (147), then hypothetically, as one of the three places where the lawyer pretends to be looking for Henry's father (244). Historically, at these times, California was a new U.S. state, having been admitted to the union in 1850, almost as soon as gold was discovered there.

OtherTexts: "Centaur in Brass", "Knight's Gambit", "Spotted Horses", "Two Soldiers", "Uncle Willy", "Vendee", As I Lay Dying, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: Texas figures in a number of Yoknapatawpha fictions, including Absalom!, as a place to run to after you've done something wrong. For example, it is speculated that Sutpen acquires the luxurious furnishings for his mansion by a scheme that, if it hadn't worked out, would have meant changing his name "and moving to Texas" (208). Similarly, it is speculated that after killing Bon, Henry "fled to Texas" or someplace even further away - "California or maybe even South America" (147). 1836, the year Sutpen comes back with the furniture, is the year Texas declared its independence from Mexico; it became a U.S. state in 1845, but at the time Henry might have fled there it was a member of the Confederate States.

OtherTexts: "Vendee"
Description: Borneo is an island off the coast of southeast Asia. In Absalom! its fabled head-hunters provide a metaphorical point-of-reference: Clytemnestra's "body just grew smaller and smaller like something being shrunk in a furnace, like the Bornese do their captured heads" (175).

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", Requiem for a Nun, The Town
Description: Italy well was known for its marble when Thomas Sutpen somehow acquired imported tombstones for himself and his wife.

Rock Island Prison, where Rosa's aunt's husband is held, was a real Union prisoner-of-war camp during the Civil War. It was opened in 1863 in Rock Island, Illinois, and became one of the Union Army's largest prisons; by the end of the war, over 12,000 Confederate soldiers had been held there.

OtherTexts: "An Error in Chemistry", Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: The University of Mississippi opened in 1844, fifteen years before Henry Sutpen and Charles Bon meet there. According to Mr. Compson, in 1859 it is "a small new college in the Mississippi hinterland" (58). The "grove at the University" where Mr. Compson speculates Henry first sees Bon is a real part of the campus (76). The two young men both attend the Law School, which opened in 1854. In the novel, as in fact, the University is in Oxford, Mississippi, which is "forty miles" from Sutpen's Hundred (249). Faulkner is also from Oxford, which is widely recognized as the original on which much of his imagined Jefferson is based, but Jefferson has no university nearby, and throughout the Yoknapatawpha fictions he puts more or less forty miles between Jefferson and both the University of Mississippi and the town of Oxford. Characters in different novels use horses or trains or cars to travel between Jefferson and Oxford, but the direction they travel remains unspecified, as if Faulkner deliberately wants to make it impossible to know exactly how to get from the real place he lived in to the one he invented.

OtherTexts: "Appendix: Compson", Requiem for a Nun
Description: The Mississippi River figures in two different ways in the novel. It is the route followed by the steamboats on which characters travel between Yoknapatawpha and New Orleans, as would historically have been the case in the decades before railroads appeared in the region; in particular the deck of a steamboat moving on the moving river - "suspended immobile and without progress from the stars themselves" (250) provides a very resonant site for Charles Bon's musings on his identity. And as "that Continental Troth, that River which runs . . . through the physical land," it is the symbolic "geologic umbilical" that connects Quentin Compson as a southerner with Shreve McCannon as a Canadian (208). In addition, the River figures in one more way as a Digital Yoknapatawpha Location, as the generic site of the anguished wandering that Charles Etienne Saint-Valery Bon and his unnamed wife undertake for "something like a year" (167). Among the men he provokes, racially, into beating him are "negro stevedores and deckhands on steamboats" (167).

OtherTexts: "Skirmish at Sartoris", "The Unvanquished", Flags in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, The Hamlet, The Unvanquished
Description: When Sutpen first arrives in Jefferson, it is clear that he is "no younger son sent out from some old quiet country like Virginia or Carolina" (11) - as elsewhere in Faulkner's fictions, for example, the first Sartoris and the first McCaslin in Yoknapatawpha are originally from "Carolina." In this context, "Carolina" (not specifically North or South Carolina) is associated with social prestige, an aristocratic pedigree. The novel does mention Charleston, South Carolina, several times, with the implication that it may be culturally superior even to Richmond, Virginia (188, 100). "Carolina" is also the place to which Henry and Bon, as part of the Confederate Army of the West, have retreated near the end of both the Civil War and the novel. The "gutted mansion of a ruined aristocrat" where, Bon tells Judith, he and his comrades found the imported stationery on which he's writing to her is probably in South Carolina, somewhere along the line of General Sherman's 'March to the Sea' (102). And "in Carolina," further on in the retreat and later on in the novel, is the "pine grove" where, amid "the gaunt and ragged men sitting or lying about" the "bivouac fires" (280), Sutpen tells his son Henry why Bon "must not marry" Judith (283).
