Description: The novel refers to a number of events that took place in the Pacific during World War II: Pearl Harbor (281), Malaya (the Malay Archipelago, which includes the Philippines, 305) and Guadalcanal (309). All references to these places in the novel are aggregated here.
Display Label: The Pacific in World War II

Description: Four miles from Holcomb House is the residence of Brother J.C. Goodyhay. Mink Snopes stays in this "small frame house" (293) on the "edge of Memphis, Tennessee" (295). The place is surrounded by a "tiny savagely untended yard" which is prelude to "even more violent desolation" in the "backyard," which "contains another house dismantled so much as collapsed - a jumble of beams, joists, window- and door-frames and even still-intact sections of siding" (293). With "no shades nor curtains," the interior of Goodyhay's house possesses "an air of violent transience similar to the indiscriminate jumble of walls and windows and doors" outside (297). The kitchen is "not spartan so much as desolate" (297), its ambience characterized by a "single unshaded low-watt bulb on a ceiling cord" (299) and a "camouflaged battle helmet" hanging on the back of the door with an "automatic pistol-butt projecting from its webbing belt" (298).

Somewhere between Lake Cormorant and Memphis, Mink stops at Beth Holcomb's to do yard-work. It's four miles from Brother Goodyhay's house, which is "one the edge of Memphis" (295). Adjacent to "a vacant lot," Holcomb's "small house" sits in "a small untidy yard" with "dead clematis vines" (291). The "minuscule front gallery" of the structure leads in to a sparsely furnished kitchen with "stove, sink, refrigerator, a table and chair" (292).

Mink Snopes is forced to stop here when he hitchhikes from Clarksdale on his way to Memphis. A real hamlet in DeSoto County located in north-west Mississippi, Lake Cormorant possesses only one distinguishing feature in the novel, for it is home to "a small tight neatly-cluttered store plastered with placards behind a gasoline pump" (285).

The shipyard where Linda Kohl works during World War II is in a real Mississippi town on the Gulf of Mexico. Pascagoula is historically part of an important military industrial corridor as it is home to Naval Station Pascagoula on Singing River Island and the Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation on the east bank of the Pascagoula River. In addition to the shipyard, the narrative includes the beach, the hotel where they stay in separate rooms, and a "joint . . . with the radio going full blast" where Linda and Gavin eat supper (276). Like the rest of Mississippi, Pascagoula is still 'dry' at this time - i.e. it is illegal to sell alcohol - which is why the waitress at that joint can only bring "glasses and ice," while Stevens has to bring "the flask" himself (276).

OtherTexts: The Hamlet
Description: In The Hamlet, Ratliff lives with his sister. In The Mansion, however, it appears that his bachelordom is inviolable apart from the occasional dinners he prepares for Gavin Stevens and Chick Mallison. Whereas there is virtually no detail in the earlier novel, in this novel Faulkner provides rich description about the location's interior layout and governing aesthetics. Ratliff keeps an "immaculate little kitchen" (256) which is adjacent to "the little immaculate room he called his parlor, with the spotlessly waxed melodeon in the corner and the waxed chairs and the fireplace filled with fluted green paper in the summer but with a phony gas-log in the winter." In the center of the room, there is a "waxed table" supporting "a rack" upon which Ratliff stores his "Allanovna necktie" within a "glass bell" (256) - a kind of shrine to his adventure in New York City.

OtherTexts: "Centaur in Brass", "The Old People", The Sound and the Fury, The Town
Description: The Negro "Sunday School" that Linda Snopes Kohl teaches at after her return from Spain (104) meets in "one of the Negro churches" in Jefferson (254). The Mansion does not specify the church's location; we have placed in near the Negro section of town that the novel refers to elsewhere.

This "so-called" fishing camp is located at Wylie's Crossing (244). Jakeleg sells bootleg whiskey from his "notorious riverbottom joint" (245). Whenever it was raided during prohibition, he would move it "one mile deeper" into the bottom (244). Consequently, Jakeleg keeps the store purposefully "unpainted" so that he can dismantle its structure at any time. Inside the little store, there are "unpainted shelves" which are "crowded with fish-hooks and sinkers and lines and tobacco and flashlight batteries and coffee and canned beans and shotgun shells." "Tacked on the wall," the "neat row of United States Internal Revenue Department liquor licenses" offers some pretense of respectability, although Jakeleg himself carefully occupies a "chicken-wire barricaded counter" through which he sells his bottles of liquor (244). Our choice for its location on the map is based on the similarities between Jackleg Wattman's at Wylie's Crossing here and Ballenbaugh's at Wyott's Crossing in The Reivers (1962).

OtherTexts: "All the Dead Pilots", "Ambuscade", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Raid", "Retreat", "Shall Not Perish", "Skirmish at Sartoris", "The Unvanquished", "There Was a Queen", Flags in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: The Sartoris plantation is one of the central locations in Faulkner's Yoknapatawpha fictions. Described in great detail in Flags in the Dust, it appears in The Mansion simply as "Sartoris," a place where Chick Mallison is planning to go to shoot quail (228).

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", The Town
Description: In the past the Backus estate, called Rose Hill (392), was one of the "biggest plantations two or three miles from town," but it falls into disrepair (217). Once Melisandre marries Harriss, the estate is extravagantly remodelled. Indeed, "what had been just a simple familiar red-ink north Mississippi cotton plantation" is "changed into a Virginia or Long Island horse farm, with miles of white panel fence" and "white stables with electric light and steam heat and running water and butlers and footmen for the horses." With Harriss' death, the estate falls again into decline. There is a discrepancy with this site's location in the larger context of Faulkner's canon. Whereas in The Town the estate is "about six miles from town" (52), in The Mansion, it is half that distance.

OtherTexts: "Ad Astra", "All the Dead Pilots", "Death Drag", "The Tall Men", "There Was a Queen", "Two Soldiers", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, The Town
Description: Bitterly evoking the idea of the war that would end all wars, Gavin Stevens describes World War I as an event that "killed eight million human beings and ruined a forty-mile wide strip down the middle of western Europe" (178). This location represents the various places in England and France that appear in the novel in the context of the war. Bayard and John Sartoris are trained in England to fly in the "Royal Flying Corps" (204). Though no combat is depicted, six French battlefields on which U.S. soldiers fought are mentioned in the text: Montdidier (199); Château-Thierry and Saint Mihiel (309); and, in his garbled fictional account of his military experience, the character who calls himself Captain Strutterbuck lists "Argonne, Showmont, Vymy Ridge, Shatter Theory" (84) - the first and third are real battles, Showmont may be his attempt to refer to Soissons, and Shatter Theory is obviously supposed to be Château-Thierry. There is also a reference to "a base hospital in France" where a woman who is related to "a Jefferson family" worked as an Army nurse (199).

OtherTexts: "Death Drag", "Dry September", "Hair", "Knight's Gambit", As I Lay Dying, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Sanctuary, The Sound and the Fury, The Town
Description: In this location we combine the novel's reference to "barbershop or poolroom" (203). As in The Town, the barbershop and the pool hall of The Mansion are virtually interchangeable, and are linked here as male environments where behind a "locked" door "at two oclock Sunday morning" the town's "boys" can be heard misbehaving in one way or another (203). For instance, Tug Nightingale has "his weekly bath in the barbershop on Saturday night," and then "gets a little drunk afterward" (203).
Tug Nightingale and his father live in a "doll-sized house" with a "minute gallery" - i.e. front porch (203). We have to speculate about where in Jefferson it's located.

This "little backstreet Hardshell church" is attended by Tug Nightingale and his father (203). The term "hardshell" refers to a branch of the Baptist religion that is extremely conservative. The novel also includes a Baptist Church in Jefferson, but that is almost certainly a larger, more mainstream branch of the faith - though throughout Faulkner's fiction the Baptists are portrayed as conservative.

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "An Error in Chemistry", "Go Down, Moses", "Monk", "Pantaloon in Black", "That Evening Sun", "The Hound", Flags in the Dust, Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Town
Description: The Mansion's second paragraph briefly recalls the time Mink Snopes serves in the county jail, "his dirty hands gripping the grimed interstices of the barred window above the street" (3).

OtherTexts: The Town
Description: The town of Saratoga, located on the eastern side of the Hudson River in upstate New York, was the site of an important American victory during the Revolutionary War. Ratliff's ancestor fought as a mercenary for the British and was taken prisoner here. "Bemis's Heights" and "Freeman's Farm" (198) were locations on which the battle's major fighting took place.

OtherTexts: "Barn Burning", "Shall Not Perish", "The Old People", Go Down, Moses, The Hamlet, The Town
Description: The mansion in The Mansion originally belonged to the de Spain family. The novel does not give any specific location for it, and throughout the Yoknapatawpha fictions the de Spain residence moves around quite a bit; we have chosen to locate it in Jefferson. The original house was "jest a house: two storey, with a gallery [porch] for Major de Spain, Manfred's paw, to set on" (170). But when Flem takes it over, he determines to make it into a "physical symbol of . . . generations of respectability and aristocracy," like Yoknapatawpha's plantation mansions (171). He hires a family member, Wat Snopes, turn it into a more stately mansion with "colyms to reach all the way from the ground up to the second storey roof" (171). Wat bases the renovations upon a "picture in a magazine" so that the "fireplaces" have "colonial molding and colyums and cornices too" (173). And Flem employs a "Memphis expert" on interior decoration to furnish the mansion (173), though in order to be comfortable, given his own poor white background, he also has Wat nail a board to the elaborate fireplace on which he can rest his feet.

OtherTexts: "Fool About a Horse", The Hamlet
Description: Ab Snopes, Flem's father, "never had come no closer [to Jefferson] than that hill two miles out, where you could just barely see the water tank" (169). This likely refers to the time Ab tried to match wits with the legendary horse-trader named Pat Stamper, a story Faulkner tells in "Fool about a Horse" (1936) and retells in The Hamlet (1940).

OtherTexts: "By the People", "Hand Upon the Waters", "Shingles for the Lord", As I Lay Dying, The Hamlet, The Town
Description: The church in Frenchman's Bend is a "Baptist church" (334). The people in Frenchman's Bend attend it regularly, "a heap of Sundays," and for "Wednesday night prayer too" (134), and Clarence Snopes teaches "a Sunday School class" there (334). This is probably also the church at which Wesley Snopes was the "revival song-leader," until he was caught with a 14-year-old girl (79).

OtherTexts: The Hamlet, The Town
Description: At least twice, Eula's suitors from Frenchman's Bend ambush the outsiders who court her at this spot, described as the "familiar bushwhacking thicket" just after the road comes "down the hill" and across "the creek bridge" (136). (In The Hamlet, which is the first text to mention this spot, there's no bridge; the road crosses the creek at a 'ford.')

OtherTexts: "Spotted Horses", "Tomorrow", The Hamlet, The Town
Description: The rambling estate of Will Varner. It is the only two story structure in Frenchman's Bend besides Mrs. Littlejohn's place.

OtherTexts: "A Rose for Emily", "Dry September", "Elly", "Hair", "Shall Not Perish", "Smoke", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, Go Down, Moses, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Sound and the Fury, The Town
Description: A drugstore on Jefferson's Courthouse Square appears in many Yoknapatawpha fictions; The Mansion is one of the texts that explicitly identifies the store as "Uncle Willy Christian's" (60). It has the same "red and green liquid-filled jars in the windows" (36) as does the drugstore in As I Lay Dying (which is not identified with Willy), and a "drug cabinet" (60), but the narrative emphasis is on its role as an ice cream parlor with tables and "soda fountains," where "young men and girls . . . eat and drink gaudy sweet concoctions" (36). In The Town Gavin Stevens spent a lot of his time 'tutoring' Linda Snopes at one of the store's tables. (Christian's drugstore in "Uncle Willy" has a separate entry, for reasons that are explained in that entry.)

OtherTexts: "By the People", "Go Down, Moses", "Hair", "Tomorrow", Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, The Reivers , The Town
Description: Gavin Stevens has an office prominently placed over the hardware store on the Courthouse Square. The room features a desk with a swivel chair.

Yoknapatawpha, like real Mississippi counties, is divided into administrative districts called "beats." In all the rest of Faulkner's fictions, the highest number assigned any beat in Yoknapatawpha is 5, but in The Mansion the narrative refers to the section "way up" in Yoknapatawpha where the Nub Gowrie makes his moonshine as "Beat Nine" (67). In Intruder in the Dust (1948), Nub lives in Beat Four, in the county's northeast. Although we don't know why Faulkner chose to renumber the beat, we are locating Nine in that same northeast corner.

OtherTexts: The Town
Description: In a back alley off the Square, Montgomery Ward poses as a commercial photographer while actually running what V.K. Ratliff calls a "nekkid picture business" (57): in the darkness of night men from as far away as "three county seats over" visited it to view the the French postcards that Monty brought back from the First World War (62). The business, and the studio, are described in more detail in The Town.

OtherTexts: "A Point of Law", "Go Down, Moses", "Monk", "Smoke", "There Was a Queen", Go Down, Moses, The Reivers , The Town
Description: Better known as Parchman Farm, the Mississippi state prison is a maximum-security facility that has been in operation since 1901. It is located in the Delta, the often-flooded part of the state that lies along the Mississippi River; when Mink looks out the window of the train carrying him to prison, he sees a "vast flat alluvial swamp of cypress and gum and brake and thicket . . . out of which man was still hewing savagely and violently the rich ragged fields in which cotton stalks grew ranker and taller than a man on a horse" (52). And the prison itself is described as a "single gate guarded day and night by men with shotguns, and inside it the low grim brick buildings with their barred windows" (54). Part of the punishment of the prisoners at Parchman, including Mink, is to work a state-owned cotton field.

OtherTexts: "Go Down, Moses", "Hair", "Monk", "Mule in the Yard", "The Tall Men", "There Was a Queen", "Uncle Willy", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Reivers , The Sound and the Fury, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: A hub of transportation and commerce, the Jefferson railroad station appears in many of Faulkner's works. When Mink goes there to spend the night at the start of the novel, it is a lively place: lit with "the red and green of the signal lamps," the horse-drawn "hacks" and one "automobile jitney" waiting outside, "the long electric-lighted shed already full of the men and boys come down to see the train pass" (38). After Mink's decades in prison, however, it is in decline: "there had not been a passenger train through Jefferson since 1935," and the railroad itself has become "a fading weed-grown branch line knowing no wheels anymore save two local freight trains more or less every day" (446). In Oxford, the train station was converted into a bus depot in 1937, so we are assuming that "the bus depot" that Charles mentions on page 199 is located here too; when Essie Nightingale goes to meet the bus from Memphis, she is described as "waiting at the station" (372).

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", "That Evening Sun", Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, The Sound and the Fury
Description: Identified as "Nigger Hollow" in The Sound and the Fury and "Freedmantown" in Intruder in the Dust, this "section" of "all Negro homes" lies between the Square and the railroad tracks (38). In The Mansion, Faulkner describes this area of Jefferson as "peaceful" and emphasizes its recent modernization. Where in his earlier fiction, the road leading through this area of town becomes a dirt road, now the section is more like the rest of town, "even with electric lights too" (38). The "small dingy back- and side-street stores which catered mostly to Negroes" are presumably located on the edges of this section (362). Toward the close of the novel, Mink re-enters the town through this same section, moving from the tracks of the rail to the first "single lonely street light" (447) and seeing a black boy on a bike.

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "By the People", "Skirmish at Sartoris", Absalom, Absalom!, Requiem for a Nun, The Reivers , The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: In eight other Yoknapatawpha fictions, the Holston House is the oldest building in Jefferson, dating back to Jefferson's origins as an Indian agency. The hotel was built by Alexander Holston, one of the county's first settlers, and is still run by his descendants, two maiden sisters. Originally a "log ordinary," the hotel had since become a "modern edifice" whose central feature is a fancy dining room which contains "two long communal tables" (421). It is described first as the place where "drummers" - traveling salesmen - stay and "sit in leather chairs along the sidewalk" (37). The description of it at the other end of the novel, however, suggests a considerably more formal place: it "still clung to the old ways, not desperately nor even gallantly: just with a cold and inflexible indomitability" so that "no man" dined there "without a coat and necktie and no woman with her head covered" (421).

OtherTexts: "Appendix: Compson", "Beyond", "By the People", "Centaur in Brass", "Death Drag", "Dry September", "Elly", "Fool About a Horse", "Go Down, Moses", "Gold Is Not Always", "Hair", "Lion", "Monk", "Mule in the Yard", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Pantaloon in Black", "Raid", "Retreat", "Shall Not Perish", "Shingles for the Lord", "Skirmish at Sartoris", "Smoke", "Spotted Horses", "That Evening Sun", "The Old People", "The Tall Men", "The Unvanquished", "There Was a Queen", "Tomorrow", "Two Soldiers", "Uncle Willy", "Vendee", Absalom, Absalom!, As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Reivers , The Sound and the Fury, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: The county courthouse and the Square around it that sit in the center of Jefferson is at the center of many of Faulkner's fictions. The Mansion describes the Square as a place teeming with life: Mink, for example, walks along the Square and sees the "young people, young men and girls in their city clothes eating and drinking" in the drugstores there (36). The novel begins inside the courthouse, with the conclusion of Mink Snopes' murder trial; also inside the building are the Sheriff's and county supervisors offices, and a room in which the "records" and documents of the county's economic and legal transactions are stored (355). Outside, the most prominent external feature of the courthouse is the "four lighted faces of the clock" that sits "on top of the building" and stands above the other buildings of Jefferson (37). The Confederate monument stands in front of the structure (223). We have also used this site to locate events that occur at unspecified places in Jefferson, as when the "Sartoris Rifles" meet (204), and to provide a location for the collective entity, the 'people of Yoknapatawpha County.' For instance, there are many times in the novel where the people act in union or believe an idea collectively. In such cases, the Courthouse Square serves as the site for these events, even though this citizenry is spread out across the county.
Other Structure: Courthouse and Square; Courthouse|Trial; Courthouse|Offices; Jefferson Event

OtherTexts: "Tomorrow", The Reivers
Description: This is an "unpainted two-storey building on a back street" (35) that Mrs. Rouncewell "calls the Commercial Hotel" while "all the rest of Yoknapatawpha County" calls it "the Rouncewell boarding house" (143). It is eventually owned by Flem.

OtherTexts: "Centaur in Brass", "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", Flags in the Dust, Light in August, The Hamlet, The Town
Description: This side-street restaurant is a regular fixture in the Snopes trilogy, and it passes from Ratliff to Flem, who uses it to build his small-town business empire. When it is first mentioned in The Mansion, it is still owned by Ratliff and is described as a "small dingy back-street eating-place" (35). After Flem takes possession, the novel refers to it as a "Dirty Spoon" (214). The "canvas tent" that Flem erects behind it is his first residence in Jefferson (140).

A slough is a narrow, shallow inlet or pond, usually in swampy terrain near a river. The narrative associates the location of "Blackwater Slough" (35) with the dam at Varner's Mill, where "the last bear" in Frenchman's Bend was seen (34).

OtherTexts: "Fool About a Horse", Flags in the Dust, The Hamlet, The Reivers , The Sound and the Fury, The Town
Description: The Jefferson hardware store becomes a site in The Mansion's narrative when Mink Snopes goes there to buy buckshot shells and Ike McCaslin, a "junior partner" in the business, refuses to sell him any (34). But much later the narrator details the history of the business, in what seems to be Faulkner's attempt to reconcile inconsistencies about the store's ownership that appear in the collected Yoknapatawpha fictions. As in The Sound and the Fury, Jason Compson works in the town's hardware store, but now the narrator explains that Earl Triplett, who owned the business in the earlier novel, is only its manager; the store is "Uncle Ike McCaslin's" (355). The narrator goes on to note that Triplett "eliminated Uncle Ike from the business" before Jason "eliminated Triplett," so that eventually "for all practical purposes Jason Compson was now the McCaslin Hardware Company" (355). This account introduces inconsistencies of its own - who was Ike's original senior partner? - but it serves The Mansion mainly to explain how Jason could afford to buy back his family's "original holding" (355).

Jody claims that Will Varner went to "a mill on Punkin Creek" (30). Although the text provides no details about where Punkin Creek is, we are assuming Faulkner is thinking of the actual "Pumpkin Creek" in southeastern Lafayette County.

OtherTexts: Intruder in the Dust
Description: A major location in Intruder in the Dust (1948), in The Mansion "Caledonia Chapel" is only casually mentioned, as the place where Mink claims he sold his cow to "the Gowrie boys" (11). Curiously, Faulkner calls the part of Yoknapatawpha where the Gowries live "Beat Nine" in this novel (67), whereas it is repeatedly referred to as Beat Four in the earlier novel (and in no Yoknapatawpha fiction do the beat numbers assigned the county's administrative districts exceed 5). In any case, we have located this "Chapel" in the place where it stands in Intruder.

OtherTexts: The Hamlet
Description: Mink Snopes lives with his family in a "paintless repairless tenant cabin" (10) somewhere in the hills north of Frenchman's Bend. The area is described as "a section of small worn-out farms tilted and precarious among the eroded folds like scraps of paper" (458). The land Mink farms is owned by Will Varner. The property is not described in much detail, but the pasture around the cabin is described as "meagre," further accentuating Mink's poverty as a sharecropper (10). When Mink finally returns here after all his years in prison, all that remains of the cabin is "part of the roof," parts of the walls, and "a hole in the ground" - what was once the cellar - which is where Mink takes refuge after killing Flem (459).

This "Negro's house" with its "empty yard" is where Mink takes his milk cow "to claim a second stand from the bull" after the first one failed to impregnate her (9). It is "three miles" from Mink's cabin, though we have had to speculate about the direction. The Negro who lives there with his family is prosperous enough to own a "scrub bull" that he hires out (9). But although the narrator calls his home a "house" three times in one paragraph, it is almost certainly what in other texts, and elsewhere in The Mansion, Faulkner calls a "cabin," a building with at most two rooms.

OtherTexts: "An Error in Chemistry", "By the People", "Centaur in Brass", "Fool About a Horse", "Hand Upon the Waters", "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", "Spotted Horses", "The Hound", "Tomorrow", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Hamlet, The Town
Description: The only store in Frenchman's Bend is one of the many properties owned by Will Varner. This furnish store is both the place where the many tenant farmers on other Varner lands are expected to buy all their supplies and the hub of the hamlet's social life. Indeed, the store is a center of economic and social relations for the community, structured upon the lien-system that emerged during Reconstruction, according to which tenant farmers are equipped from the store and consequently saddled with a "furnish bill" (310) that they have to pay off at the end of each growing season. The "front gallery" or porch (8) of the store appears to be constantly occupied by a number of men who never buy anything, but are simply there for conversation. The store is initially run by Jody Varner, but is then taken over by Flem Snopes who, in turn, relinquishes responsibility to his family members.

OtherTexts: "The Hound", The Hamlet, The Town
Description: The spot that Mink picks for his ambush is described as a "thicket" fifty yards down from where "the road from Houston's to Varner's store crossed the creek bridge" (42).

OtherTexts: "Miss Zilphia Gant"
Description: This icon represents the "back streets around the edge of town" where Ratliff is driving while telling Chick about Montgomery Ward Snopes' "canteen business" (120).

LocationTitle: Cotton House Where Wesley Snopes Is Caught
OtherTexts: The Mansion
Description: Located somewhere in Frenchman's Bend, this "empty cotton house" is where the "a posse of enraged fathers" finds the Snopes who had teaching the school and holding "revival services and baptisings" having sex with "a fourteen-year old girl" (43).

LocationTitle: Bridge over the Creek at Frenchman's Bend
OtherTexts: "Spotted Horses", The Hamlet
Description: The wooden bridge over which one of "them wild Snopes ponies" (35) escapes is located "just this side of Bookright's turn-off" - i.e. the road that leads to Bookright's farm (36). Because Ratliff can hear the horse's hooves as it crosses, the bridge must be fairly close to Mrs. Littlejohn's.

OtherTexts: "By the People", "Hand Upon the Waters", "Shingles for the Lord", As I Lay Dying, The Hamlet, The Mansion
Description: The church in Frenchman's Bend is run by Mrs. Varner "with the cold high-handedness of a ward-boss" (289). Our decision about where to located it is based on a passage in The Hamlet: when Mrs. Armstid looks "up the road" from Varner's store, she sees (in this order) Mrs. Littlejohn's, the school, and then, the church.

Owned by Uncle Noon Gatewood, the Jefferson blacksmith shop is located "on the edge of town" (68). Gatewood is described as "yellow," a term which identifies him as a light-skinned Negro - making this one of the few black-owned businesses mentioned in the fictions.

Gavin tries to convince Linda Snopes to leave Mississippi to attend one of "the smart 'finishing' schools north of Mason's and Dixon's" (221). The Mason-Dixon line, named for the two surveyors who drew it in the 1760s, is often used to represent the boundary between The North and The South as two parts of the U.S. As examples of the schools he has in mind, Gavin lists "Bennington and Bard and Swarthmore" (224). Our icon appears on the Vermont site of Bennington, an all-female college until after the novel was published. The other schools, however, don't seem to fit Gavin's "finishing-school" designation. Bard College, in New York state, was all-male until 1944. Swarthmore, in Pennsylvania, has been co-educational since its founding in the 1860s.

OtherTexts: "Ad Astra", "Centaur in Brass"
Description: Gavin Stevens wryly concedes that he knows the "young" Mr. Stone, "even if he did go to New Haven" (342). The reference is to Yale University, in New Haven, Connecticut, traditional Ivy League rival of Harvard, where Gavin himself went.

OtherTexts: "Ambuscade", "Appendix: Compson", "Raid", Absalom, Absalom!, Requiem for a Nun, The Unvanquished
Description: "Chickamauga and Lookout Mountain," in northern Georgia and southern Tennessee, were the locations of two major Civil War battles fought in the fall of 1863 (152).
The United States Military Academy at West Point, where Manfred de Spain went, has trained officers for the Army since 1802.

OtherTexts: "Appendix: Compson", "Uncle Willy", Absalom, Absalom!, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion
Description: Three different locations in California, and California itself as a destination, are mentioned in The Town. "California" is linked with "Texas" and "Mexico" as a place to run away to (346). Chick references "San Francisco's Chinatown" - "half the world or anyway half the continent" away - when he notes that these is one "Chinaman" who lives in Jefferson; "we all knew about San Francisco's Chinatown" (321) - "we" of course being the white townspeople. And the "limousines" at the funeral of Melisandre Backus' husband would not have shamed "Hollywood itself" (187). It's not clear what Chick knew about Hollywood, but by the time he wrote The Town Faulkner himself had worked there often as a screen writer, beginning in 1932 and ending only when he no longer needed the money.

When World War I ends, the event is celebrated with the ringing of "the courthouse bell" and "all the church bells too," on all "the Sunday steeples" around town (118). This icon represents those various churches. One of them would be the Episcopal church, mentioned separately in the novel as "the oldest extant building in town" (321). The novel does not mention the denomination of any of these other churches, but the other three main denominations in Jefferson and Yoknapatawpha are Baptist, Methodist and Presbyterian - all Protestant.

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", Absalom, Absalom!, Flags in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion
Description: Well known for its marble and sculpture craftsmanship, Italy is where Gavin sends a photograph of Eula to have a medallion carved to fasten to her monument.

OtherTexts: "Fool About a Horse", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, The Reivers , The Sound and the Fury
Description: Doctor Peabody's office is located above Christian's drugstore. (Since Digital Yoknapatawpha can't display Locations vertically, we've located in just north of the drugstore.)

OtherTexts: "Hair", "Shall Not Perish"
Description: Relatively new to Jefferson, the local "ten cent store" is where shopping bags are given away to customers (242). (Also called "five-and-dime" or "nickel-and-dime" stores, these stores were distinguished for the variety of low-cost merchandise they stocked. The first such stores were opened in Pennsylvania by the Woolworth Brothers in the late 19th century. By the early 20th century they were common in the South.)

New Market is apparently a hamlet in Yoknapatawpha County where Gavin Stevens goes to a "supervisor's meeting on some more of the drainage canal business" (268). "Some more" seems to connect with an earlier reference to the "squabble over a drainage tax suit" (181) in Wyott's Crossing, so we have located New Market near that other location. But It does not appear in any other fiction, so we have no clear evidence as to where Faulkner imagined it to be.

LocationTitle: Road Between Jefferson and Frenchman's Bend
OtherTexts: "Fool About a Horse", "Hand Upon the Waters", "Shall Not Perish", "Spotted Horses", "The Hound", "Two Soldiers", Light in August, The Hamlet, The Mansion
Description: In this novel, the road from Frenchman's Bend to Jefferson is identified as the "southeast road" (4).
The tailor shop is owned by Mr. Kneeland and is where all the men in Jefferson rent their "dress suits" for the Cotillion Ball (73).

LocationTitle: Snopes Children's Camp in Frenchman's Bend
Description: After Flem sends them to Frenchman's Bend, Byron Snopes' children build "a play house or cave or something in another ditch about a half mile up the road" (387) from Varner's store. "Play house" seems very inappropriate when they tie Clarence Snopes "to a blackjack sapling with something less than a cord of wood stacked around him" and light it on fire (388).

OtherTexts: "Shingles for the Lord", As I Lay Dying, Sanctuary, The Hamlet
Description: Tull's farm is one of the Yoknapatawpha locations that Faulkner moves around to suit the demands of his various fictions; however, it is always near Frenchman's Bend. In this novel it is near Dewitt Binford's home.

Dewitt Binford and his wife, nee Snopes, live "near Varner's store" in Frenchman's Bend (383). That's where Flem Snopes sends children of Byron Snopes and an Apache woman - "the four Snopes Indians or Indian Snopeses, whichever is right" (381) - to stay after their misadventures in Jefferson. The children have a room and a bed, but prefer to drag a "quilt off onto the floor" and lie on it: "the bedstead itself dismantled and leaned against the wall in a corner out of the way" (384).
The four children whom Byron Snopes sent to Jefferson have "a camp or reservation or whatever you might call it in a cave they dug in the big ditch behind the school house" (382).

The Widringtons live in one of Jefferson's new developments in town, built after the streets were paved. The Widringtons have a Cadillac and a dog "that they said cost five hundred dollars" (380). When not riding in the Cadillac, the dog is seen "sneering out through the window in the house where it - they - lived" (381).

OtherTexts: "Appendix: Compson", "Uncle Willy", As I Lay Dying, The Sound and the Fury, The Town
Description: The Mississippi State Insane Asylum - which Ratliff refers to as "the Jackson a-sylum" (75) - was located in the state capital, Jackson, until 1935.

When Provine leaves camp to go to the mound, he travels down "the road that went down the bottom" (72). Given the fact that the woods in the story are called a "jungle of cane and gum and pin oak" (65), this "road" is probably more like a path.

LocationTitle: First Hunting Stand in Big Woods
Description: A deer-hunting "stand" can be a structure, a platform attached to a tree that allows the hunter to wait a dozen or so feet above the ground for his prey to walk past - or "stand" can simply mean a specific place on the ground, usually against a tree, where the hunter waits. In either case, when a group is hunting, "stands" are a way to make sure that everyone in the party knows where the other hunters are. In this story, the "deer standers" are spaced in at least three places along the railroad track that runs through the woods; this first stand is occupied by Ike McCaslin (69). The fact that Ike "turns" to Provine, who is sitting "down on a log behind" him, suggests that the stands in this story are simply assigned spots "along the log-line levee" (69).

LocationTitle: Third Hunting Stand in Big Woods
Description: A deer-hunting "stand" can be a structure, a platform attached to a tree that allows the hunter to wait a dozen or so feet above the ground for his prey to walk past - or "stand" can simply mean a specific place on the ground, usually against a tree, where the hunter waits. In either case, when a group is hunting, "stands" are a way to make sure that everyone in the party knows where the other hunters are. In this story, the "deer standers" are spaced in at least three places along the railroad track that runs through the woods; the hunters at this "next" stand order Provine back to the camp when they hear him, and his hiccups, coming their way (69).

LocationTitle: Second Hunting Stand in Big Woods
Description: A deer-hunting "stand" can be a structure, a platform attached to a tree that allows the hunter to wait a dozen or so feet above the ground for his prey to walk past - or "stand" can simply mean a specific place on the ground, usually against a tree, where the hunter waits. In either case, when a group is hunting, "stands" are a way to make sure that everyone in the party knows where the other hunters are. In this story, the "deer standers" are spaced in at least three places along the railroad track that runs through the woods; this "next stand" is occupied by at least two unnamed men (69).

OtherTexts: "Lion", Go Down, Moses
Description: In Faulkner's hunting stories, a "log-line" is a temporary spur railroad that has been built by a lumber company to carry the trees they cut down out of the woods. Therefore the story's "log-line levee" is probably an earthen dyke that has been built to keep the tracks from being flooded when the river rises, though it could instead be the raised and flattened bed on which the tracks run (69).

In this story a "remnant" of the "once powerful" Chickasaw tribe still lives in the Yoknapatawpha in the 20th century, "under Government protection," in "their own settlement," apparently a kind of reservation that includes their own "store" (65). Historically, however, almost no federally sanctioned Chickasaws remained in the region after they were removed west of the Mississippi River in the 1830s. In addition, the story's Chickasaw culture is organized around a large Indian mound - although historically the mounds were built by an aboriginal people who inhabited the land well before the arrival of the Chickasaws.

"Five miles . . . down the river from Major de Spain's camp," in a "wilder part of the river's jungle," is the topographical feature Ratliff calls "an Indian mound" - "the only elevation of any kind" in the "flat jungle of river bottom" (65). Many real earthen mounds, built at different times over almost two thousand years by the aboriginal peoples who once occupied Mississippi, still exist. The frame narrator calls the mound in this story, where he and a friend once spent a sleepless night, "profoundly and darkly enigmatic" (65), and indeed there are still unanswered questions about the origins and purposes of many of the mounds. Ultimately in this tale the "dark power" of this particular mound is used comically, as a great way to cure hiccups - or take revenge (65).
The African-American church that is the scene of the picnic where Ash first tangled with Provine is "a few miles from town" (64) - though the text doesn't tell us in which direction.

In this story, Major de Spain's hunting camp includes a "kitchen" that, in the fashion of many of the larger residences in Yoknapatawpha, is in a separate building (71): when Ratliff tries to summon Ash, the black servant who is in charge of the kitchen, he goes "to the door" of the camp itself, and yells "towards the kitchen" (74). Like other such kitchens, this one is a racially defined space, the place where the story's black characters can usually be found when they are not serving the white men in the hunting party.

OtherTexts: "Appendix: Compson", "Delta Autumn", "Dry September", "Lion", "The Bear", "The Old People", "Wash", Absalom, Absalom!, Go Down, Moses, The Reivers , The Town
Description: The hunting camp owned by Major de Spain stands in the wilderness of the river bottom "twenty miles from town" (63). Although only occupied about two weeks a year, during the fall hunting season, it seems to be a fairly substantial structure, complete with a separate kitchen in the fashion of larger southern houses.

OtherTexts: "A Point of Law", "A Rose for Emily", "Appendix: Compson", "Centaur in Brass", "Death Drag", "Dry September", "Elly", "Fool About a Horse", "Go Down, Moses", "Gold Is Not Always", "Hair", "Lion", "Monk", "Mule in the Yard", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Pantaloon in Black", "Race at Morning", "Raid", "Retreat", "Shall Not Perish", "Shingles for the Lord", "Skirmish at Sartoris", "Smoke", "Spotted Horses", "That Evening Sun", "The Old People", "The Tall Men", "The Unvanquished", "There Was a Queen", "Tomorrow", "Two Soldiers", "Uncle Willy", "Vendee", Absalom, Absalom!, As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Reivers , The Sound and the Fury, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: Courthouse Square sits at the center of both the town of Jefferson and the county of Yoknapatawpha, and appears in most of Faulkner's Yoknapatawpha fictions in various ways. In "A Bear Hunt" it is explicitly mentioned as the site where the Provine gang likes to shoot off pistols "late on Saturday nights" (64). In Digital Yoknapatawpha we also use the Square as a default location for (1) scenes that take place in undefined parts of Jefferson, as when Ratliff meets a few "fellows" when he "gets back to town" from the woods (66), and (2) the scene of story-telling when a text does not locate a first-person narrator anywhere in particular - so in this case, the Square is where both the unnamed frame narrator and Ratliff tell the story.

OtherTexts: "Ad Astra", "Appendix: Compson", "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", Flags in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury, The Town
Description: When describing the graveyard at the Old Frenchman's place, the narrator refers to the slaves buried there as "the progenitors of saxophone players in Harlem honkytonks" (375). This reference re-frames the narrative in both time and space, relocating it briefly from Yoknapatawpha in the present (the 1890s) and the past (the antebellum era of slavery) to the New York City of the 1920s, by which time large numbers of southern blacks had moved to the urban North and when jazz was in vogue among both white and black audiences.

OtherTexts: "Go Down, Moses", "Hair", "Knight's Gambit", "Mule in the Yard", "The Tall Men", "There Was a Queen", "Uncle Willy", As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Mansion, The Reivers , The Sound and the Fury, The Town, The Unvanquished
Description: The railroad station appears frequently in the Yoknapatawpha fictions, as the main portal linking Jefferson to the larger world. In The Hamlet in only appears once, obliquely, as the site through which the traveling salesman who has been courting Eula Varner flees after being attacked by the local young men who are competing for her attention.

OtherTexts: "The Unvanquished", "Two Soldiers", Absalom, Absalom!, Requiem for a Nun, The Unvanquished
Description: It is from Kansas City (the city in Missouri) that Wall Snopes' butcher orders "special meat" for Mrs. Widrington's Pekingese (380). (From 1871 till the great flood in 1951, Kansas City was well known for its stockyards, and thus for its beef, in particular the Kansas City strip steak.)

Coca Cola opened bottling plants throughout the state of Mississippi beginning in 1906. The plant appears to be on the outskirts of town where Byron Snopes's children are found, the little one with syrup spilled down the front of its nightshirt (379).

OtherTexts: The Mansion
Description: The American victory over the British in the Battle of Saratoga (1777) was a decisive victory for the colonies in the Revolutionary War. According to Eula, Ratliff's "six or eight or ten times grandfather" was an ensign in the British army that surrendered there (338).

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "Appendix: Compson", "Hand Upon the Waters", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Skirmish at Sartoris", "The Unvanquished", Absalom, Absalom!, Requiem for a Nun, The Reivers , The Unvanquished
Description: Carolina is a generic term that Gavin Stevens uses to talk about the migration of the settlers to Yoknapatawpha from Scotland, settling first in Carolina: the "hill-country of McCallum and Gowrie and Frazier and Muir" that translated intact "from Culloden to Carolina, then from Carolina to Yoknapatawpha" (332).

OtherTexts: "Appendix: Compson", Intruder in the Dust
Description: Much of the white population of Yoknapatawpha is of Scottish descent, particularly the "hill-country of McCallum and Gowrie and Frazier and Muir" that translated intact "from Culloden to Carolina, then from Carolina to Yoknapatawpha" (332). Gavin Steven's description here implies that these settlers were attracted to Yoknapatawpha by the similarity between its hill country and their original homeland.

LocationTitle: Ridge where Gavin Stevens Sees All Yoknapatawpha
Description: "Beyond Seminary Hill," the "mild unhurried farm road" that Gavin Stevens is driving along "mounts to cross the ridge and to join the main highway leading from Jefferson to the world" (330). Pausing atop this ridge, Gavin takes a long, reflective look at "all Yoknapatawpha" spread out beneath him (330).

Located at Seminary Hill (named for the school called the "Seminary" that Melisandre Backus and Maggie Mallison once attended, 52), this "small dingy store" is owned by old Mr. Garraway (328). It is a place for men to gather and talk while eating cheese and crackers. Gavin describes it in some detail when he depicts Garraway himself "standing there behind the worn counter which he had inherited from his father, racked with tins of meat and spools of thread and combs and needles and bottles of cooking extract and malaria tonic and female compound" (328). These items suggest a female clientele, but in the novel the customers Gavin mentions seeing there are black and male, "loafing Negroes" (327).

OtherTexts: The Mansion
Description: Readers learn that Jefferson has a "beauty parlor" where women in town go for hair styling and other beautification treatments when Chick Mallison sees Eula's hair: "as soon as you looked at her you could tell that's where she had been" (324). The text provides no evidence, though, of its location.

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit"
Description: "The oldest extant building in town," the small Episcopal church was "built by slaves" (321). According to Chick Mallison, the "Northern tourists" who expect Jefferson's architecture to be a lot older than it is, call the church "the best, the finest too" (321). Although most of Jefferson and Yoknapatawpha are Baptist or Methodist, the Episcopalians, along with the Presbyterianians, are the oldest congregations in the county, going back to the days before Jefferson was officially a town.

OtherTexts: The Mansion
Description: Mrs. Ledbetter lives six miles out of the way from the route between Frenchman's Bend and Jefferson. The text doesn't say six miles in which direction, but the name of the place she lives - "Rockyford" (308) - suggests it's a place where you can cross the river, so that is where we have put it.

OtherTexts: "Dry September"
Description: The brick yard is a place where bricks are made. In "Dry September" it is described as abandoned, but in this novel it must be operational since it is where Grover Cleveland Winbush is the night watchman there.

OtherTexts: "A Bear Hunt", "Appendix: Compson", "Uncle Willy", As I Lay Dying, The Sound and the Fury
Description: The Mississippi State Insane Asylum - referred to in the text as the "Jackson asylum" - was located in that city, the state capital, until 1935. In addition to Benjy Compson in The Sound and the Fury and Darl Bundren in As I Lay Dying , the narrator tells us his is where Henry Armstid is locked up for life after falling victim to Flem Snopes's buried money scheme at the Old Frenchman's bend mansion. (Jackson is mentioned again in the novel when Wall Snopes arranges to deliver a Jackson newspaper in Jefferson.)

LocationTitle: Non-Yoknapatawpha Tenant Farms Ab Snopes Worked
OtherTexts: "Barn Burning", The Hamlet
Description: Flem Snopes grew up in a family of sharecroppers who repeatedly moved from one "worn-out tenant farm" to another (275). According to "Barn Burning," in his young life Flem's younger brother Sarty has lived at "a dozen" of them. The farms that are specifically mentioned in various texts are owned by De Spain ("Barn Burning"), Anse Hollard (The Hamlet) and Will Varner (the Snopes trilogy) - these are all in Yoknapatawpha. Our map uses the location we assign the farm at the beginning of "Barn Burning," which is owned by a landlord named Harris; it's in Grenier County. Presumably most of the places the Snopeses worked were out of Yoknapatawpha, since Jody and Will Varner have not heard of them when Ab contracts to work one of the Varner farms in Frenchman's Bend.

OtherTexts: "All the Dead Pilots", "Ambuscade", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Raid", "Retreat", "Shall Not Perish", "Skirmish at Sartoris", "The Unvanquished", "There Was a Queen", Flags in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Mansion, The Unvanquished
Description: Chick Mallison goes to shoot quail at a place he refers to only as "Sartoris" (254). This is the large plantation that John Sartoris built during the antebellum period and then rebuilt after it was burned by Yankee soldiers during the Civil War; it appears in many of the Yoknapatawpha fictions.

OtherTexts: "Mule in the Yard"
Description: The text does not say who Mr. Spilmer is, but the "ravine ditch behind Mr. Spilmer's house" is presumably close enough to Mrs. Hait's property (264) for her to walk there with the mule.

OtherTexts: "Mule in the Yard"
Description: Directly across the street that runs in front of Mrs. Hait's house is the neighbor's house, which has a gallery and rocking chairs where Mrs. Hait and Het sit watching her house burn down.

OtherTexts: "Mule in the Yard"
Description: This "cowshed" in the corner of Mrs. Hait's back yard is connected by wooden planks to Mrs. Hait's house (248). After her house burns down, Mrs. Hait moves into the shed and shares it with her cow.

OtherTexts: "Mule in the Yard", Flags in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion, The Unvanquished
Description: This "sharp curve" on the railroad track "below town" provides I.O. Snopes with an extra source of income: since engineers driving the north-south train can't see the mules he has Mr. Hait put on the track in time to stop, he can charge the company for their "accidental" deaths. The scheme works well until Mr. Hait becomes a casualty himself.

OtherTexts: "Mule in the Yard"
Description: Mrs. Hait's house is located on the edge of town near the railroad tracks. It is a "little wooden house painted the same color that the railroad company used on its stations and boxcars" (243). Beside the kitchen door is "the wooden lid of the cellar stairs" (244), "wooden steps at the back door" that lead to "the wooden planks" which form a path to the "wooden shed in the corner of the back yard" where the cow lives (244). After the fire, all that's left of the house are "two blackened chimneys," and all that remains of all this wood is "still-intact cowshed," into which Mrs. Hait moves (257).

OtherTexts: "Mule in the Yard", Flags in the Dust
Description: Before the Social Security Act of 1935, many localities in the U.S. had "poor houses" or "poor farms" to give destitute elderly or handicapped people some place to live (at poor farms they were often required to work for their support). The Yoknapatawpha poorhouse where Old Het lives - "That is, she used the poorhouse to sleep in or anyway pass most or at least part of the night in" (241) - is located a mile and a half from Jefferson.

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion
Description: The "Academy" is the Jefferson institution of higher education for women that Linda Snopes attends for a year and a half after graduating from high school. The generic term for it would probably be 'a finishing school.' Gavin Stevens calls it an "anachronistic vacuum" (303): "one of the last of those gentle and stubbornly fading anachronisms called Miss So-and-So's or The So-and-So Female Academy or Institute whose curriculum included deportment and china-painting, which continue to dot the South though the rest of the United States knows them no more" (300). According to Gavin, the "dwindling few" young women who attend are taught that "not just American history but all history had not yet reached Christmas Day, 1865" - because the Civil War "was not done" (301).

OtherTexts: "A Rose for Emily", "Gold Is Not Always", "Miss Zilphia Gant", Flags in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun
Description: Bringing together consumer goods that had previously been purchased in more specialized shops, department stores began appearing in the U.S. in the late 19th century. The one in Jefferson has large plate-glass windows displaying merchandise and is big enough that it has a "luggage department" (210). In this novel it is given a name - "Wildermark's" (208).
Sheriff Hampton lives somewhere in Jefferson, but although the narrative says that Matt Levitt's car is taken to the sheriff's home, it does not say where that is.

"Caledonia" is the name of the place where Matt Levitt gets into a fight with Anse McCallum (206). There is a real Caledonia in Mississippi, a town in Lowndes County, north of Columbus and near the Alabama border; this town is mentioned in The Unvanquished. But the "Caledonia" in The Town must be in Yoknapatawpha, since the Yoknapatawpha county sheriff arrests both young men for fighting there. In Intruder in the Dust Caledonia Chapel is in the hills northeast of Jefferson, and in Flags in the Dust and elsewhere the McCallums (or MacCallums) live in the northeast corner of Yoknapatawpha, so that is where we have chosen to locate the scene of the fight. Presumably it is a hamlet like Frenchman's Bend.
AuthOtherTexts: Flags in the Dust, Intruder in the Dust

Description: Ford was the most popular brand of automobile sold in the U.S. through the 1920s. This company "agency," or dealership, may be the same as Jefferson's first car agency, the one opened by Manfred de Spain, but it's just as likely that the town soon has more than one dealership. Having been trained in the "new Ford mechanic's school," Matt Levitt was sent to Jefferson by the Ford company "to be a mechanic in the agency garage" (192).

OtherTexts: "A Justice", "Appendix: Compson", "Hair", "Knight's Gambit", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Race at Morning", "Red Leaves", "The Old People", Absalom, Absalom!, Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Mansion, The Reivers
Description: New Orleans, Louisiana, is home to both Melisandre Backus' husband - "a big rich . . . bootlegger" (187), and "the Italian consul" who helps Gavin Stevens acquire the "carved marble face" that adorns Eula's monument.

Located a mile and a half from the spring and creek bottom from which his wife carries water daily, Wilbur Provine's house has a "path worn smooth as a ribbon and six inches deep from his back door to the spring where he had walked it twice a day for two years until they caught him" for making moonshine (177) .

OtherTexts: Intruder in the Dust
Description: Yoknapatawpha County is "dry" - i.e. it is illegal to sell or possess alcoholic beverages there. But for decades the country people have surreptitiously made their own liquor in "moonshine stills." This still is owned by Wilbur Provine, who supplies moonshine to the residents of Frenchman's Bend. It is "located in the creek bottom by a spring about a mile and a half from his house, with a pathway worn smooth as a ribbon and six inches deep from his back door to his spring where he had walked it twice a day for two years until they caught him" (176).

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", "Uncle Willy", Flags in the Dust, Intruder in the Dust, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury
Description: The Dixie Cafe is an alternative place to Christian's drugstore to buy ice cream on the Square - Ratliff buys Chick a cone there (171). We assume it is the same 'Jefferson restaurant' that appears in other texts under four different names, including "the Cafe" in "Uncle Willy."

OtherTexts: Intruder in the Dust
Description: The town marshals, one who works in the daytime and another who works at night, have a "station" located on the Square where they can wait between their rounds (167). This is presumably a small structure designed to provide a good vantage point on the happenings of the town.

OtherTexts: "Skirmish at Sartoris", The Unvanquished
Description: Located near the Blue Goose Cafe (167), the "gin and compress" is where the local farmers take their harvested cotton in the fall for processing: the gin mechanically separates the usable cotton from the seeds, and the compress compacts that cotton into bales for shipment outside the county.

One of the rare black-owned businesses in Yoknapatawpha, the "Blue Goose" is "a Negro cafe below the cotton gin" (167). Since it stays open "every night" until the town night marshal "runs all" the patrons out "and closes it up" (168), it may be more like a juke joint - that is, an African American night spot featuring music, dancing and gambling as well as drinking - than a restaurant.

Near to the tent where Snopeses live when they first reach Jefferson is the store that serves as the launch point for Wallstreet Panic Snopes' success story. When Wall begins working there as a janitor and "afterschool-and-Saturday clerk and errand boy," it is a "grocery store about the same class as the Snopes cafe" (135). With the money from his father's death, he buys into the store, and becomes the owner when "the old owner died" (152). Business savvy, Wall first rented and then bought "the store next door and converted it into a warehouse, stock room, so he could buy in larger wholesale lots for less money; another few years and he had rented what had been the last livery stable in Jefferson for his warehouse and knocked down the wall between the two stores and now we had in Jefferson the first self-service grocery store we had ever seen, built on the pattern which the big chain grocery stores were to make nation-wide in the purveying of food" (157). (This self-service "pattern" - pioneered by a Piggly-Wiggly store in Memphis in 1923 - is by now very old and familiar: instead of asking a clerk behind a counter for what they want, customers were given direct access to the aisles and shelves.) Wall also adapts retail to the automobile age: "the street his store faced on made an L with the alley where the old Snopes restaurant had been so that the tent in which he had passed his first night in Jefferson was directly behind his store too; he either bought or rented that lot . . . and made a parking lot and so taught the housewives of Jefferson to come to town and seek his bargains and carry them home themselves" (157).

OtherTexts: "Appendix: Compson", "Gold Is Not Always", "Knight's Gambit", "That Evening Sun", "Vendee", Go Down, Moses, Light in August, The Hamlet, The Sound and the Fury, The Unvanquished
Description: St. Louis is referred to twice in the novel. Both the bonding company that insures the public officials in Jefferson and the wholesale grocery company that supplies Wall Snopes' store are located there.

"Virginia" is where V.K. Ratliff's ancestor escaped from captivity as a prisoner of war during the American Revolution, becoming the family's first American. And Virginia, specifically Bristol, is where Miss Vaiden Wyott goes to teach after leaving Jefferson.
AuthOtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "Knight's Gambit", "The Tall Men", Absalom, Absalom!, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury

OtherTexts: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", The Mansion, The Reivers
Description: "Wyott's Crossing" (over the Tallahatchie River) is mentioned twice in the novel. In the passage describing Vaiden Wyott's origins also provides the early history of the site: her family came from the country, "where they had owned the nearest ford, crossing, ferry before Jefferson even became Jefferson" (154). By the era of The Town it is now the site of a bridge. In his capacity as County Attorney, Gavin is planning to drive up there with Chick, to help resolve the locals' "squabble over a drainage tax suit" (181) - though in the event they don't make the trip.

OtherTexts: "Elly", "Gold Is Not Always", Go Down, Moses, The Mansion, The Reivers
Description: The "old Bank of Jefferson" (149) is as old as the town itself, having been founded in "1830 or so" (280). As the other bank in town, it is the rival of the newer Sartoris Bank, and the bank into which Flem Snopes (although Vice President of the Sartoris Bank) moves his money in a complicated maneuver directed against his kinsman Wallstreet Panic Snopes.

LocationTitle: Old Man Snopes' House outside Town
Description: Bought for "old man Snopes," whom some believe is Flem's father and others his uncle, this is "a little house about a mile from town where he lived with an old maid daughter and the twin sons named Vardaman and Bilbo that belonged to I.O. Snopes's other wife" (136). Because this Snopes refuses to get any closer to Jefferson than this spot, "they bought" this house for him (136); "they" must be other Snopeses, but which ones is not made clear. The "house had a little piece of ground with it, that old man Snopes made into a truck garden and water-melon patch" (137). According to Chick Mallison, old man Snopes doesn't sell or eat the watermelons: they are "bait for the pleasure or sport or contest or maybe just getting that mad, of catching boys robbing it; planting and cultivating and growing water-melons just so he could sit ambushed with a loaded shotgun behind a morning glory vine on his back gallery until he could hear sounds from the melon patch and then shooting at it" (137).

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", Intruder in the Dust, The Mansion
Description: According to Chick Mallison, Jefferson's high school is distinct from the grammar school (197). Gowan Stevens attends the high school while he lives in Jefferson (47), and Linda Snopes also attends the high school, which seems to be somewhere on the far side of the Square from her home since she meets Gavin "on her way home from school" for ice cream (197). And although Wallstreet Panic Snopes' school experiences take place in "kindergarten" and "second grade," and describe Jefferson's grammar school in a bit more detail than any other text, his story also refers to "the highschool rostrum" on which he will someday receive his diploma (153).

OtherTexts: "Hair", "Miss Zilphia Gant", "Uncle Willy", Intruder in the Dust, The Sound and the Fury
Description: Wallstreet Panic enters kindergarten here, where he meets his second grade teacher to whom he later proposes in her classroom, the "empty room itself smelling of chalk and anguished cerebration and the dry inflexibility of facts" (153). All the text says about the location of the building is that it is too "far away" from the Square for Gavin to hear its dismissal bell (217). There is no mention in the novel of the school which the Negro children would have attended.

OtherTexts: The Mansion
Description: Opened by Montgomery Ward Snopes after he returns from the First World War, the Atelier Monty transforms a corner store "with a side door on an alley" (127) into what Gavin Stevens calls "a pay-as-you-enter peep show with a set of imported pornographic photographs" (282). The building is owned by the Compson family. The photographs were brought back by Monty from France after World War One. The people of Jefferson are led to believe it is "a photographing studio" (128), and Snopes does take some photographs that can be displayed in the windows. But as the town eventually discovers, the "dark room" in the back was really where he used a magic lantern to project "pictures of men and women together, experimenting with one another" (171): "most of his business was at night like he did need darkness, his trade seeming to be mostly men now, . . . and the customers going and coming through the side door in the alley" (131).

OtherTexts: "Barn Burning", "Shall Not Perish", "The Old People", Go Down, Moses, The Hamlet, The Mansion
Description: The De Spains, father and son, appear often enough in Faulkner's fictions and the history of Yoknapatawpha to make the family one of the county's more important ones. In fact, the titular Mansion of the novel that follows The Town in the Snopes trilogy is the "big wooden house" that Manfred de Spain's father built (14) and that he lives in in this novel, until Flem moves in at the end. However, it's not possible to be sure where to put this mansion on a map. Faulkner moves it around quite a bit in the seven texts that include it. In "Barn Burning" and The Hamlet, for example, it's clearly a plantation with tenant farmers someplace in the county, but in "Shall Not Perish" it's close enough to Jefferson's Courthouse Square for Mrs. Grier and her son to walk there. Since Manfred is the major of Jefferson in this novel, it seems reasonable to assume that Faulkner imagined him living in Jefferson, but beyond that our decision about its location is speculative.

Ohio is where Matt Levitt is from and where he won the Golden Gloves and attended the "new Ford mechanic's school" (192). The novel doesn't say where in Ohio, however. The airfield where young Bayard Sartoris dies testing an experimental "aeroplane" - which elsewhere is located in Dayton, Ohio - has its own entry in the database (125).

OtherTexts: Flags in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion
Description: The novel briefly recalls the scene, described in detail in Flags in the Dust, where Colonel Bayard Sartoris dies in a car accident. The event occurs when he and his nephew, also called Bayard, "come over a hill at about fifty miles an hour" and have to drive into "the ditch" beside the road to avoid hitting "a Negro family in a wagon" (124).

OtherTexts: "Elly", Flags in the Dust, Sanctuary
Description: The novel mentions both the University of Virginia, which at the time that Gowan Stevens is preparing to enroll there was all-male, and "the Virginia schools at which Southern mothers seemed to aim their daughters" (220-21), which at the time of the novel would include all-female colleges like Mary Washington and Sweet Briar.

OtherTexts: "A Rose for Emily", "Beyond", "There Was a Queen", "Vendee", Absalom, Absalom!, As I Lay Dying, Flags in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury, The Unvanquished
Description: Like many other characters in the Yoknapatawpha fictions, two characters in this novel end up buried in the town cemetery. Eck Snopes, or all that was recovered of him - the neck brace that is found "hanging in the telegraph wires about two hundred yards from where the tank had been" (116), is laid to rest here by the Masons in charge of the funeral (117). Eula Varner Snopes is also laid to rest there, in a "new" section in that is "empty except for the one raw excavation" (360). Later, Flem Snopes erects a column that features a sculpture of Eula's face carved in Italy that stands "at the head of that one grave that hadn't quite healed over yet, looking - the stone, the marble - whiter than white itself in the warm October sun against the bright yellow and red and dark red hickories and sumacs and gums and oaks like splashes of fire itself among the dark green cedars" (372).
Cedric Nunnery is playing here, "about a half mile away" and "up the track" from the depot, when the explosion occurs (116).
Mrs. Nunnery lives with her son Cedric in "a little house just up the hill from the depot" (115).

OtherTexts: "Appendix: Compson", "Knight's Gambit", Go Down, Moses, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion
Description: The novel associates "Mexico" with lawlessness in two different ways. Chick Mallison says Byron Snopes "escaped to Mexico" after robbing Colonel Sartoris' Bank (113) - and later imagines Flem might do the same thing. And the mother of Byron's children, who seem completely untameable, is "a Jicarilla Apache squaw in Old Mexico" (379).

OtherTexts: "Ad Astra", "Appendix: Compson", "Lizards in Jamshyd’s Courtyard", Flags in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury
Description: New York City is mentioned as the place from which Gavin Stevens catches a ship to Europe as a young man before the war. And the specific part of the City known as Greenwich Village is where he arranges for Linda to go after her mother's death; Gavin describes it to Chick as "a place with a few unimportant boundaries but no limitations where young people of any age go to seek dreams" (367).

OtherTexts: Light in August, The Sound and the Fury
Description: The place where Gavin Stevens changes trains to "catch the express from Memphis to New York" in this novel is identified as "Mottstown junction" (107). (In Faulkner's other Yoknapatawpha fictions, this change would occur north of Yoknapatawpha, in the town he calls "Memphis Junction.") Mottstown is the seat of the county just south of Yoknapatawpha, so it may also be the town "in the next county" where Flem and Eula marry (6), though that is also confusing; several other fictions state that they marry in Jefferson.

OtherTexts: The Hamlet, The Mansion
Description: More fully described in The Hamlet as being near a ford, the "dark road" in Frenchman's Bend is where the Eula's suitors ambush McCarron and Eula in the buggy.

LocationTitle: Bottom and Slough in Frenchman's Bend
OtherTexts: "The Hound", The Hamlet
Description: A "slough" is a swamp, though in this case it refers specifically to the pool of stagnant water into which Mink Snopes throws his shotgun after killing Zack Houston; the gun is later found by "some fish-grabblers" - i.e. people who are trying to catch fish with their bare hands (84).

OtherTexts: "The Hound", The Hamlet, The Mansion
Description: Mink kills Houston on a road that that runs beside a "thicket" somewhere between Houston's land and Varner's Store in Frenchman's Bend (83-84).

OtherTexts: "The Hound", The Hamlet, The Mansion
Description: Zack Houston - called Jack in The Hamlet - is "a good farmer" who, unlike the many tenant farmers in the Bend, owns his farm outright (82). His wife is killed by there by his stallion.

OtherTexts: "A Point of Law", "Go Down, Moses", "Monk", "Smoke", "There Was a Queen", Go Down, Moses, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion, The Reivers
Description: The "penitentiary at Parchman" (82) to which Mink Snopes is sent for killing Zack Houston is the Mississippi state prison better known as Parchman Farm. It is a maximum-security prison that has been in operation since 1901.

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "An Error in Chemistry", "Go Down, Moses", "Monk", "Pantaloon in Black", "That Evening Sun", "The Hound", Flags in the Dust, Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, Sanctuary, The Hamlet, The Mansion
Description: The county jail is where Mink Snopes spends two and a half months before being tried for killing Zack Houston. Because he is a white prisoner, or as V.K. Ratliff facetiously puts it, "a authentic topclass murderer," he is not held in the common room with the black prisoners who "go out and work on the streets" in the chain gang, but by himself "on the top floor of the jail" (85).

OtherTexts: The Mansion, The Reivers , The Sound and the Fury
Description: "Opera House" was the way playhouses were often referred to in towns where the religious community frowned on play-acting. "Opera" sounded culturally more respectable than plays, though actual operas were seldom staged in them. By the late 1920s the advent of movies had closed or taken over a lot of small town playhouses. In The Town, it is where the Cotillion Ball is held (75). This location includes the "back alley" in which Gavin and Manfred fight.
The flower shop, owned by Mrs. Rouncewell because "she loved funerals" (73), is where all the men in town order flowers for the ladies who attend the Cotillion Ball.

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "By the People", "Skirmish at Sartoris", Absalom, Absalom!, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion, The Reivers , The Unvanquished
Description: Also referred to the as "Holston Hotel" (88) and in The Reivers as the oldest and finest hotel in Jefferson, it is where many traveling salesmen ("drummers") stay in Jefferson (63).

OtherTexts: "Appendix: Compson", "Dry September", "Hair", "Knight's Gambit", "Pantaloon in Black", "Shall Not Perish", Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion
Description: Referred to as the "picture show," the town's movie theater plays two shows each evening (162).

OtherTexts: "A Name for the City", "Ambuscade", "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek", "Retreat", "Skirmish at Sartoris", "There Was a Queen", Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion, The Reivers , The Unvanquished
Description: The "creek" that flows behind the Sartoris place and toward the Tallahatchie River appears in several other texts, but is given a name in the story "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek.": "Hurricane Creek" is its official designation, but everyone calls it "Harrykin Creek" (697). In The Town, Chick Mallison refers to it as "Harrykin Creek," which is frozen solid, daring Aleck Sander to jump into it. "right through the ice, clothes and all" (56).

OtherTexts: "Knight's Gambit", The Mansion
Description: Melisandre Backus lives with "her father and a bottle of whiskey" on "a plantation about six miles from town" (52). The text gives no other clue to its location, but almost all Yoknapatawpha's big estates are north of Jefferson. And this is a big estate, despite the word "farm" in the description of what happens to it after her father dies and she marries a rich New Orleans bootlegger, who transforms it from "just another Mississippi cotton farm" to one with "white fences and weather-vanes in the shape of horses so that it looked like a cross between a Kentucky country club and a Long Island race track" (187-88).

OtherTexts: "Death Drag", "Dry September", "Hair", "Knight's Gambit", As I Lay Dying, Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Sanctuary, The Mansion, The Sound and the Fury
Description: Only mentioned in the novel - by Maggie Mallison, when she notices that Gavin's hair looks "shaggy" - the town barbershop is busy on Saturdays (52).

OtherTexts: "An Error in Chemistry", "By the People", "Hand Upon the Waters", "Knight's Gambit", "Tomorrow", Intruder in the Dust, Light in August, Requiem for a Nun, The Mansion
Description: The house where the Stevens and Mallisons live is owned by Gavin and Maggie's father: "We were all living with Grandfather then. I mean Grandfather was still alive then and he and Uncle Gavin had one side of the house, Grandfather in his bedroom and what we called the office downstairs, and Uncle Gavin on the same side upstairs, where he had built an outside stairway so he could go and come from the side yard, and Mother and Father and Cousin Gowan on the other side while Gowan was going to the Jefferson while he was waiting to enter the prep school in Washington to get ready for the University of Virginia" (47). On its grounds are a "pear tree in the side yard" and a "pink dogwood" (325).

OtherTexts: "By the People", "Go Down, Moses", "Hair", "Knight's Gambit", "Tomorrow", Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust, The Mansion, The Reivers
Description: Gavin Stevens' office, as both a lawyer and as County Attorney, is located above McCaslin's hardware store right on Jefferson's Courthouse Square (92). It is reached by climbing a set of outside stairs. Its prominent location explains his anxiety when Eula Snopes visits him there after dark (94).

OtherTexts: "A Bear Hunt", "Delta Autumn", "Lion", "The Bear", "The Old People", Go Down, Moses, Intruder in the Dust
Description: The "Big Bottom" is Faulkner's name for a large wilderness area on the Tallahatchie River in the northwestern corner of Yoknapatawpha County, as described most vividly in his novel Go Down, Moses. In this text, Colonel Sartoris is described as "of that group of old Major de Spain's bear and deer hunters when Major de Spain established his annual hunting camp in the Big Bottom shortly after the war" (45).

SourceTextTitle: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek"
Description: Sometime after the Civil War, Philip and Melisandre move into a house where Bayard sees "framed under glass" Granny's letter about the death of Lieutenant P. S. Backhouse (696). The story provides no clue about where the couple is living, but a generation or two later Melisandre Backus grows up in Jefferson; her marriage to Gavin Stevens is narrated in The Mansion (1960). On that basis we have located this house in town.

SourceTextTitle: "My Grandmother Millard and General Bedford Forrest and the Battle of Harrykin Creek"
Description: The spot "twenty miles ahead" of the Tallahatchie Crossing, where Lieutenant Backhouse has led his troop "trying to find something to lead another charge against" (692). He is placed under arrest here by General Forrest's provost.

OtherTexts: "By the People", "Dry September", "Mule in the Yard", "That Evening Sun", "There Was a Queen", Flags in the Dust, Requiem for a Nun, The Hamlet, The Mansion, The Reivers , The Sound and the Fury
Description: Occasionally referred to in other texts as the Farmers' and Merchants' Bank, and in The Town as the "new bank" (44), the "Sartoris Bank" is one of the town's two banks.
